It could have used a bit more sage, but I enjoyed it and would definitely would order it again.  Their dessert menu includes my all time favorite, panna cotta and it was excellent.  I can't speak for the dessert menu itself, I didn't need to see it since panna cotta was an option.  I was there on a Friday night during the busy time and there were tables with larger groups including children, I had no trouble with service.  I can't speak to the specific label of the cabernet sauvignon, but was very happy with the server's selection for me.  I'll definitely be here again next time I'm in town.  My Italian is too rusty to keep up with the conversation, but loved hearing the language again.
author: Theresa M.

description:
What better than to jumpstart a completely random "Lets be Tourists of San Francisco" weekend at Mona Lisa.

It's gawdy, the menu is massive and the waiters have Italian accents. Hello North Beach, where have you been all of my friend's life? Erica H. was in town for the full on extravaganza and after a bitch of a plane ride filled with girls clicking their gum and being general "in air" catty messes she was in desperate need of food, drink and more food. Now if I knew of a good greek restaunt that would have been great but her being an SF virgin, she needed her cherry popped.

So off we went to North Beach on a Friday night. It was about 8:00pm or so and we were able to get seated right away, and to make it an even sweeter deal we sat in a front window. Starving marvins that we are, we ordered a bottle of wine and an appetizer plate filled with a caprese salad, roasted garlic cloves and something else. I am a natural born garlic fiend and when in doubt I will easily eat a roasted garlic clove without any shame. I enjoyed that part out of the entire meal, the cloves were beauties and I'm sure my body wreaked for a full 24 hours but it was worth it. 

For the entrees:

Seafood risotto
*Light white sauce with a huge selection of Mussels, Clams and Fresh Calimari. 

Seafood tomato base sauce Linguine
*Savory sauce, not heavy by any means. Nice assortment of mussels and calimari.

Of the two I enjoyed the risotto best, I'm not a big pasta or rice fan and know  should have gone with a non-pasta dish but when am I ever eating in North Beach?

The service was fantastic and our glasses were never empty. Mona Lisa made for a pleasant way to introduce my friend to a quirky part of SF.
author: Morgan M.

description: Stopped by here for a quick dinner when I was traveling by myself. Staff were super friendly and lovely! I had spaghetti carbonara and it was amazing. I was sitting outside and they had their cute little car parked up in-front of the restaurant and the owner insisted I sit in the car and have dessert on the house :)
author: Sarah J.

description:
Ah, my favorite Italian Restaurant in San Francisco.  The food was delicious, the customer service superb, the ambiance is so inviting & relaxing!  

Oscar & Julian are great!

Can't wait to visit again.
author: B. O.

description:
This is my 2nd favorite Italian Restaurant. The pasta dishes are always delicious, their large appetizer plate comes full of all sorts of things from cheese to meats to olives etc. They have a really decent wine selection too. It's a little more "old school Italian" feel to it than the other restaurants in that area. I go there a few times a year for the past 7 or 8 years.
 I do have to admit - sometimes the way they treat you is based on your appearance (ex: I get better service it seems when I'm dressed for a night on the town as opposed to when I wear jeans & a big jacket or something) which is a downer. 
But if you want the better Italian food with the Italian experience, go here. Food is always good.
author: Samantha M.

description:
I'm shocked to see the reviews with 1 or 2 stars for this place.  My boyfriend and I were in town for the holidays and happened upon this restaurant.  With so many options to choose from on Columbus we were willing to pass it by.  But the host offered us free bruschetta as an app if we came in.  Nuff said - in we went.

Perhaps it was the holiday spirit or the fact that it was a Wednesday afternoon and I wasn't at work - but I found the whole experience to be lovely.  We were offered a seat by the window which was cozy and inviting allowing us to see outside but also have a great view of the beautiful restaurant.  (They also offered a seat deeper into the restaurant so I don't feel they were trying to make the place look busy as other reviewers have said.)  I was craving pizza so we ordered one to share along with some caprese salad and our free app of course.  

All of the food was delicious.  The pizza was incredible and there was plenty for two people and left overs to give to a homeless guy we later by the wharf.  The service was pretty good, not excellent but doable.  There were only about 5 tables being used in the place but again, it was a Wednesday afternoon.  We never felt rushed or forgotten but we were also in no hurry and were in great spirits so perhaps I overlooked small things that would have otherwise annoyed me.

Nevertheless, I'm glad I didn't read all of the reviews on Yelp before checking this place out.  I am happy to have tried it out myself with no bias or expectations.  Perhaps that is why we loved it so much, because we didn't know what to expect.

Overall, I recommend this place - at least mid-day, mid-week.  Get a pizza, it was fantastico!
author: NNB G.

description:
Old School, Old School, Old School. Great Old Restaurant with a cool ambiance. I make it there every trip to the Bay Area. There is a great table up in front. The place is shaped like a slice of pie with the point facing the street, there is a table in the tip of the point that offers good street views, and some relief from the crush of customers. (they are generally slammed) The Menu is quite large, with an incredible assortment. The wine menu is similarly large. The Spaghetti all' Amatriciana is not to be missed ( Pancetta, Onions, Parmesan and an incredible simple tomato base) nor is the Ravioli alla Zucca (Pumpkin stuffed ravioli with a brown butter sage sauce) 

It;s hard to NOT like this place. Actual Italians making Italian food, just imagine it.
author: ken s.

description: What a terrific family restaurant.  If you have ever been to Italy you would truly appreciate the restaurant and the owner. We were greeted outside and immediately sat down.   The restaurant was full with families and everyone was happy. The owner made sure to go around to each table as he spoke Italian. My friends and I had a great waiter who recommended a very good bottle of wine. We enjoyed appetizers and we all had pasta dishes. OUTSTANDING! We were not disappointed the fish was fresh and the pasta dishes were hearty and filling. Based on what we ate and also being in North Beach we thought our bill would be pricey. Surprise it was not. Great value and even more great people. Thank you. We will be back.
author: Rick O.

description:
While on our quest for Italian food and a bottle of wine, we ducked in here after seeing the extensive menu which includes many types of meat/seafood/vegetarian dishes, including pastas, pizza, and other fare. The atmosphere is cute, and the waiters were attentive. I really enjoyed their Mona Lisa ties :)

The bruschetta appetizer was on the house, and we really enjoyed it. There are a good deal of entrees for about $15, and bottles of wine start around $40. Although reasonably priced, though, I was not overwhelmingly impresses by my entree, the meat lasagna. Rather than in a loaf it was overwhelmingly doused in meat sauce, and there was too much black pepper. The veggie lasagna and eggplant parm were served the same way, and my friends agreed that the food was ok, but not amazing. Dessert (tiramisu) was also good-- I liked that it was served with a raspberry sauce-- but again, I've had better.

Although I did like the decor and atmosphere, with so many choices in this area, I probably wouldn't come here again.
author: Alissa B.

description:
We had dinner last saturday at Mona Lisa and i think it was one of the best meal I had, the food delicious,very tasty!! The host offer us some appetizers on the house, very good also, the service also excelent, our food on time , and a smile on each and every worker there, something that you dont see  very often, from dishwashers to the owner that was also there making sure we enjoy .
We are going back fou sure !!!!!
author: Julio G.

description: The gnocchi is really tasty!  If you are in North Beach and are craving italian, this is a good stop.  It's WAYYY better and slightly less touristy than the Stinking Rose.
author: J R.

description:
EXCELENT Italian Restaurant!!!  
Bruschetta, coppa , proscitto for antipasto
Fantastic Saltimbocca with some good red wine. 
Tiramisu and profiterole for dessert. 
What a great dinner and night. Seemed to be back home
author: Alberto M.

description:
First of all, to the adorable blue-eyed waiter who said I looked like Shakira tonight, message me so we can have a drink.  :)

Now, on to business.  In an effort to please my dear mommy after a hectic day of crowds at the festival, tons of walking and really nothing she particularly liked, we headed back to North Beach for an Italian meal.  They seated us right away, I was kinda surprised since NB was extra shitshow.  Anyhoo, my eggplant was really good, the sauce was great.  The spinach that came along was awesome.  Mama had spaghetti & meatballs, she was into it.  We shared a house salad and it was pretty big, defs enough to
 share.  Yummy mixed greens too, not useless iceberg or romaine.  Portions were large, we had to leave a lot behind.  (mom's got a hotel room so I'm staying with her)  Um, the menu is huge.  Like small type and four pages.  It's all there.  Basically, Mom was happy, I was happy...everybody wins.
author: Emily T.

description:
One word:  AWFUL!  If I could give it negative stars I would.

This restaurant irritated me.  The food was horrible, the service was crap, and the atmosphere tacky.  Its worst than a tourist trap.  I've been here once before for a birthday party and it was not that bad.  We came here late on a whim because Franchino was closing and remembered that it was ok.  The minute we walked through the door, they weren't sure where to seat us, so we were standing in the way of all the service, while they were hashing it out in Italian.  

I ordered a coke and it was totally flat, so I asked the bus boy to get another.  Because he doesn't speak English well, he just shrugged his shoulders.  I had to say "there is no gas" in the drink.  It seemed like he finally understood that and he took it away to bring another.  After 15 minutes, no new coke!  I then called the manager over for another problem.  I caught a baby cockroach under the lamp as it was running across our table.  Yuck!  The managers response, "Oh we did not invite him tonight.  I give you complimentary meal."  At this point, I was so skeptical, that I knew the bill would not be adjusted.  Finally, got a coke "with gas" after telling the manager. 

On to food... I asked the waiter if the rigatoni with sausage and eggplant had any cheese on it.  He said no, so I ordered it.  (I am lactose intolerant).  When the meals came, it was smothered with cheese.  It looked disgusting even if I could eat it that way.  I told the waiter that he said the dish came without cheese and his response, "What? You don't like Mozzarella?"  He finally seemed to understand when I said I was allergic and had one remade.  I seem to remember Mozzarella being in the cheese category.  This is where the Italian accent and language is not charming at all, if that is what you're into.

My husband's meal sucked as well.  They screwed up spaghetti and meatballs  - sauce was too watery and meatballs were tough, dry, and overcooked.  And the garlic bread, was worse than if you bought day old bread, hacked it up, and spread some year old margerine, and 10 year old garlic powder on it.  It was gross and bitter.

At the end of the meal the busboy gives us a tiramisu.  We told him we didn't order it.  He walks away, comes back and drops it on our table.  Again, told him we didn't order it and he shrugs his shoulders and practically runs away.  When the waiter came with the bill, we told him we didn't order the dessert and he tells us its complimentary.  Yea!  Here is our complimentary meal.  A sad looking piece of tiramisu that I can't eat because I'm lactose intolerant.  Thanks, but no thanks.  There's probably be a baby cockroach inside for a delightful surprise!  The waiter immediately took it back. 

Lastly, during our meal, the manager and the cook (notice I don't say chef) were arguing loudly.  The cook was pissed about something and was slamming things around and throwing dishes down on the pick up line.  This kitchen is open to the restaurant so you can see everything.  It was really distracting.  

As predicted, full charge for the whole meal.  I was so irritated I didn't even want to argue with the manager and just paid the bill.  It was the most expensive crappy meal I've ever had.  $50 for 2 dishes, garlic bread and a coke.  I walked out really wishing we had gone to McDonalds and that is only in emergency situations.  I doggy bagged the rest of my meal and gave it to a stoned homeless guy on the street.  He'll probably eat it with no problems because he's stoned and has the munchies, not because he's homeless. 

If you are not a tourist and you liked this place... Shame on you.  SF has so many other sub-par Italian restaurants that are better than this, never mind all the other awesome ones there are.  If you are a tourist, avoid this place like the plague.  Don't be conned by the ropers on the street with their Italian accents trying to pull you in.  Instead, only have coffee and dessert at a cafe here in North beach or see a strip show.  Then go to Incanto, in Noe Valley, for good italian.  Even Chris Constantino's Offal menu of organ parts will be richly more satisfying than Mona Lisa's awful S**T.   (Sorry and No Offense Chris, I shouldn't even mention you in the same breath as this place).
author: D G.

description:
So disappointed in this place.  After obsessively yelping places to go for my 21st birthday in December (I know.  This review is delayed), I ended up choosing Mona Lisa - I can't really remember why.  I ended up having just a really weird experience here.  

There were about 10 of us, and we were seated right at the front at this awkward long table with a pathway behind it where waiters were constantly walking back and forth.  That alone wouldn't have been a problem, but the whole staff was so rude!  As soon as we sat down and before we really got a chance to look at the menu, a waiter came up to my friend who was sitting next to me and asked her if we'd like a sampler tray, in a very pressuring way.  My friend, who I'm guessing felt awkward with him hovering over her, said yes.  It wasn't until we looked at the menu that we realized the sampler platter was something like TEN DOLLARS A PERSON (this would be sixty dollars for our group), which the waiter conveniently neglected to tell us.  My friend flagged him down and asked him to please cancel, as we didn't know the cost of it when he asked us, but he told us that they already started cooking it so they couldn't cancel it???? 

The meal pretty much went downhill from there.  The food was nothing special, and it was way too overpriced - I had the baked ravioli and they were pretty mushy and gross, and I don't think anyone was crazy about anything they got.  We mentioned it was my birthday and the waiters were super snotty about it, didn't say happy birthday or anything like that and it was just really uncomfortable.  

I hate complaining about restaurants and I usually don't, but I just had to.  Definitely would not return here.
author: Mandy B.

description:
I had dinner with 4 other colleagues here at Mona Lisa Restaurant in LIttle Italy, San Francisco. The food and service was spectacular. The interior decorations are colorful and animated in sense. 

The restaurant was full most the night but the service and food was never compromised. The did a good job in taking care of us. I definitely recommend this restaurant to others and I will return again.
author: Donald P.

description: This is my wifes favorite restaurant in SF.  It's one of my favorites too.  We've been going for 6 years or so.  It's always crowded but it's worth the wait.  Their home made meatballs and meat sauce is great, and I think the calzone is great also.
author: Matt R.

description:
Holy hot pants Batman.  This is some good stuff.  I had the Gnocchi Fondenti (baked four cheese-cream sauce nutmeg). CHEESE GALOR!  I was very happy I waited to have my eat what I want day for Wicked in SF with my sister and boyfriend for the CHEESE GALOR!  My plate came nice and hot with little chunks of baked cheese around the rim.  The amount of cream sauce was perfect, not to much or too little and if you have some bread left over you can pick some of the leftover sauce with the bread.  

We had reservations at 5:45 but got seated early so that was a plus.  Our waiter was very polite and helpful.  The food....fantastic.
author: Adrian B.

description:
I was really trying to think off at least one reason for not leaving a review of a place as good as this... And I didn't manage to do that as you all can see! The food that I had couple nights ago was absolutely fabulous(Lasagna de Casa), and the friend that I'd went with thinks no less of his dish(Viel pinnio, I think). I would have to say, that having a opportunity to grow up with Italy in the neighbourhood has given me a chance to taste some of authentic Italian food, and trying this place definitely remind me of the food back in the days.

Not only the ambient is nice and cozy(great spot to dine with your girl), the staff was very nice and courteous, they also had a good choice of genuine Italian wines. The one that waiter picked out for us was delicious with a lot of taste(Machiavelli). Everything was arranged nice and the price was not too much for the service that we've got...
Would definitely recommend and coming back for sure!;)
author: Zee K.

description: I went here for Valentines Day dinner with my bf. It is a very cute lil resturant. The owner is a crazy Italian man and very nice. He greets the cutomers at the door and calls all the ladies "bellas". The decoration inside reminds me of a tacky themed las vegas hotel, but I loved it. Mona Lisa's has plenty of food option sto choose from. I ordered the gnocchi al pomodoro and my bf ordered some dish similiar to a ciopinno with pasta. Overall the food and atmosphere were great.
author: Nava N.

description: My coworkers and I went to this restaurant after attending a convention that was in town. The atmosphere is amazing and the owner is one genuinely nice guy. When I noticed that a colleague of mine had a drink in a 49ers glass, I asked the waiter where I could obtain a glass like that (my wife is a big 49ers fan), I was surprised when the owner came up with a brand new glass wrapped up for me. This was a very unexpected surprise, it was a very nice touch! The food here was amazing, I had the lasagna al pesto and it was cooked perfectly. I would definitely visit this place again when I am in town.
author: Cliff D.

description: Mona Lisa s always my go to restaurant when I go to the city. They always have excellent service! This last week it was pouring and North Beach was dead, except Mona Lisa! They were packed with a line out the door. My favorite dish is their cioppino. It is always so delicious and I cant wait to go back! A real taste of Italy! :~)
author: Michelle M.

description: I started eating at Mona Lisa over ten years ago and I always get treated like I'm at home. Living in San Francisco I'm always playing tour guide for friends and family when they come into town and at least once a month I do parties of 20 to 30 people at a time at Mona Lisa and when they return for another visit to our beautiful city they always want Mona Lisa to be on the list of places we eat. The food is outstanding, the staff will treat you like family and the atmosphere is always fun. I highly recommend it over and over again.
author: Ronnie O.

description:
What a very unfortunate brunch experience we had.  Well, let me rephrase...LUNCH experience.  Despite booking a table for 11:30 on a Sunday, please be advised that Mona Lisa does not serve brunch.  It serves standard Italian fare.  Ok, that one is on me as I made a wrong assumption; however, the rest of the experience is on Mona Lisa.  

When we arrived, despite us having reservations and the restaurant having only 2 other tables occupied at that time, they were not set up for our party of 6.  We waited while they set it up.  From the time we sat down until the time we were served was over an hour (no appetizer, just in desperate need of our main course).  This might not read like a long time in a review, but an hour is an extraordinarily long time when waiting for a meal.  I had to follow up on the whereabouts of our meal about 50 minutes in.  When the meal finally arrived after an hour, they served 3 of the 6 of us.  It took another 5-10 for the next 2 to be served.  When the final dish arrived (after now 5 of us had been eating for 10+  minutes), it was the wrong dish entirely.  That member of our party had to wait another 15 minutes for the kitchen to make him the correct meal.   The other two tables were not getting much better service.  Also, it bears mentioning that I indicated in our Open Table reservation that we were celebrating a birthday.  Nada.  No mention of it, no happy birthday mention, and certainly no house dessert or the like. 

I was deeply disappointed in this experience and was embarrassed that I had selected it for our meal.
author: Penny P.

description:
I absolutely loved the decor of Mona Lisa and I thought it has a very cozy environment. They had a wide selection of pastas, entrees, salads, etc to choose from. They also had a huge wine list. I thought the pasta I had was good, but nothing spectacular. The first time I had a lasagna and the second time I had a spaghetti. THe tiramisu was really good. THe wine was standard for an italian place.

If you come to Mona Lisa, you come for the ambiance. But you can find italian food like this anywhere. It was not anything spectacular.
author: Mai L.

description: Holy gnocchi!!! The Mona Lisa has the best gnocchi, hands down. We tried both the Quattro Fromagi and the Fondenti and were more than satisfied. Like any good Italian restaurant, we were beyond full about half way through the delicious bowl of gnocchi. Another highlight was the Margherita Pizza. My nephew said it was the the second best pizza of his entire life and he absolutely loved the wait staff. The atmosphere was warm and inviting and smelled absolutely divine. The only thing that left me dissatisfied and with tummy troubles was the house Pinot Grigio. It was terribly acidic and deeply upset my stomac. Overall, our experience was wonderful and we will keep coming back! Mona Lisa is the best place in North Beach for Italian food and fun!
author: k s.

description:
My man was tired - he deserved to be taken out to dinner for damn sure.. 

so we grabbed our little dog and walked over to North Beach, looking for a restaurant with sidewalk seating. " Steps of Rome" just looked a little too touristy so we went over to the Mona Lisa. 

First of all we were hustled by a guy selling roses, who told us he'd told the host we were looking for dinner - he definitely looked like he poked his head in there and said something anyhow. 

10 minutes later, and $5 poorer, finally someone came out and changed the dirty tablecloths. That, i was willing to chalk up to the buds hustler, but then it took ANOTHER 7 minutes to bring out bread and water. 

And there we sat. With bread, olive oil, vinegar and water, for another 15 minutes... and my man was HUNGRY. Meanwhile, the waiter had brought the cheque for the table next to us, then cleared it - not even bringing us menus or acknowledging us . 

Finally Iran ( my man) went IN to the restaurant and brought out menus himself.

3 pieces of bread later, and nobody had taken our order. 

We gathered up our $5 roses, and went across the street for dinner. 

At least that rude, rude restaurant is out a loaf of bread. 

I should have stolen their vinegar.
author: Domini A.

description: Service was sub-par, bruschetta was soggy, wine was delivered to the table as a 2009 vintage when on the menu it was a 2006. Waaaaay too pricey and an automatic 20% gratuity was tagged on. Which i understand because of our party of 6, but 20%, come on!! Pretty soon you'll be expected to pay 30%. The tip should be equivalent to the service.. When asked about the wine, they just said they're menus are old. Well, i have an idea.... with all that money you are bringing in, change them.
author: Brandan P.

description:
I would highly recommend the 4 cheese lasagna, the mixture of flavors pleases the pallate!  We had initially ordered the meat lasagna but am glad they were out because the lasagna we ended up with was simply incredible!

The waiter was awesome as well and because they were out of what we ordered, he gave us a free entree - on the house.  

The food and customer service were impecable!
author: Todd G.

description:
Of the restaurants that i've been to in North Beach, I always like coming to the Mona Lisa.  It's a fun atmosphere, which the tacky, antique like vases and paintings on the walls.  It's definitely decorated, but not in an organized fashion... that's what makes it so fun.  I also love their picture of the Mona Lisa... look for it because I'm not going to ruin it here. =P

I think it's always a plus when you have real Italian waiters.  The accent is just sexy! ;)  

Anyway... onto the food...  They have good, tasty, fresh bread; a large variety of pastas, and regular dishes ranging from $14-25, depending on what you get.  I like their lasagna here... and I'm a picky lasagna person--i hate having too much ricotta cheese...here, they make it with LOTS of cheeeeessseeee.... YUUUUMMM.  I can't remember exactly what I've gotten here, but I know their portions are pretty big, and their pastas are pretty good, which have lots of flavor.  I believe that I've had the lasagna, chicken parmiagiana, and tortelloni.  All were delicious!

Definitely want to come back here soon!
author: Diane L.

description:
It was my mom's last night on her visit to SF.  We decided to head to  North Beach for dinner.  There are so many restaurants there...how do you choose.  Do we go somewhere I've eaten before or go somewhere that friends have suggested.  Decisions, decisions, decisions.

Upon our walk on the search of where to dine, every place was offering either a free appetizer or glass of wine with our meal.   we ended up at Mona Lisa where I had dined before maybe five years ago and couldn't remember how great it was.  

What we ordered:

Penne al Forno alla Calabrese 
baked penne with meat sauce, ham and mozzarella

Fettuccine Mona Lisa 
cream sauce, ham, olives and mushrooms 

Portions were huge!  Mom and I should have ordered just one entree.  My leftover was enough to fill me for lunch today.  I'd return, but will opt out of getting anything that included ham because the dishes were on the salty side.  If you're big on ham, these dishes will not disappoint.
author: Michelle N.

description: I've eaten at Mona Lisa 3-4 times as I visit SFO somewhat frequently.  I really enjoy this place - although it's probably a simple presentation of basic Italian.  The decor is gaudy and garish - but mostly I think it's done with a wink and provides a nice 50s "supper club" feel.  The house salad with vinaigrette dressing was just awesome!  Not sure how they made it so good, but it was spectacular.  My wife got a sea food pasta dish in white wine sauce. It was light and well stocked with muscles, squid, etc.  I got the gnochi pomodoro with a meat ball side.  It was tender and delicious.  Our wait staff was generous with their wine pours and attentive to our needs.  This may not be the best place in North Beach - but it's completely serviceable and a fun experience. Go try it!
author: Josh H.

description: Gnocchi Sorrentina with fresh mozzarella was excellent. Gnocchi was perfect and the sauce was delicious. The Macara (cheese ravioli, meat and veggie cannelloni were good too.
author: A A.

description:
Sorry Mona Lisa - you were a disappointment.  

Though I have my N. Beach fav - Pinocchios - I am always down to try something new, hoping to discover a new favorite to add to the list.  Unfortunately, this will not be one of them.

Came last Mon. about 8pm and were sat right away at a cute corner table outside under heatlamps (+).  We asked the waiter's advice for a bottle, he gave us some info to mull over.  I didn't think that meant he wouldn't be back for 20 mins. just to take the bottle order (-).  Good thing the bread came during our wait so we had something to snack on, the bad thing is it wasn't very good - no flavor, dry, and a little stale (-).

We ordered the crostini app which includes three crostinis, each topped individually with prosciutto, smoked salmon, and traditional bruschetta.  All were very good (+), however portions are pretty small for the price $12.95 (-).

To start we shared a house salad - decent size, lightly dressed (+). Then ordered a seafood pasta that is usually in a tomato based sauce but we were feeling indulgent and asked if it could be in a cream sauce.  No problem with our request (+). I ordered the vegetarian lasagna.  

I have to admit, the food was very good. The seafood was very fresh and the lasagna was decadently baked and served with plenty of rich cheese.  Very, very rich, I could barely get through half (++).

The two star rating is that the service was PAINFUL.  We always had to flag down our waiter (including to take out credit card to pay our bill). From the moment we sat down to the moment we finished it was a constant game of "where is our waiter ?" I wish I could say it was because he looked busy with other tables but actually it was because there was a lil' situation with a homeless girl close to the restaurant, cops showed up and he decided he would chit chat with the cops, take their to go order and completely forget that he had actual tables to attend to.  

I mean, if you go for the food, I can't hate on them here but for me, service is a CRUCIAL element of the dining experience and bc of this it's a no on the 2nd go.
author: Kristine T.

description:
I have been to this place a few times...
Once I was there with friends, about 10 of us and received great service.I always look for a place which serves good food, affordable and a place you can be with friends. Its definitly a loud place, but hey at times thats fun! The ambience is rustic with old memorabilias, which makes the experience rather interesting. However its a little tight of space, but the food makes it all worth!
author: Lisa H.

description:
Our waiter was terrible.... 20 mins before he  took our order.
Another  15 mins before we got our drinks and that was only after I went an found another waiter and asked for our drinks.

 I ordered veal parmigiana...oh my god was it tough I had to hack through it with a steak knife!!!! The table bread was also stale. The coffee was burnt.

 I couldn't find the waiter  anywhere so that I could send my plate back... 

We waited 20 more minutes before getting up and walking to the front to find the manager; however they still made us pay for one meal... they seriously should have comped up the entire meal!!!

This was to be a celebration dinner(as my friend had just gotten a job offer) but our night was ruined!!!

Also I left my scarf at the table and went back but couldn't find it. At this point  someone else was sitting at our table... looked all over... came back and lifted up the jacket of the lady sitting there.... she had stuffed it under her to hide it (it's a very high-end designer scar)...and I yanked it out from under her butt....she gave me a nasty look. Ugh scarf had to be dry cleaned.

ugh... I will never go here again.... it's a tourist trap and the food is terrible....
author: Shauna M.

description:
Mona Lisa is by far my favorite restaurant in the bay area.  I love Italian food and like to think that I have an educated opinion on it, since I've had the best (Gnocchi in Sorrento, Italy...mmmmm) and the worst (let's see....Chef Boy Ardee Ravioli that my friend's mom used to force down our throats when I was young! lol).  Mona Lisa is not quite up to par with the best dishes I had while trekking around Italy, but it holds its own.

This place is usually packed, so expect a bit of a wait to get in (usually only about 15-20 mins).  The wait staff is fairly attentive, though some are more friendly than others.  It's dimly lit inside and tightly packed...a perfect place to bring a date, or a small group of friends, but if you have a large group eating together, you would probably be more comfortable elsewhere.

North Beach is full of Italian Restaurants and I have tried quite a few of them.  But, do yourself a favor and pass up the stench of the Stinking Rose and treat yourself to the Pollo San Marino at Mona Lisa instead.  Pair that tomato cream sauce with the dryness of a Chianti and you will be in your happy place for the rest of the night.
author: Pablo O.

description: Love love love this place!! The owner and waiters are actually Italian! It reminded me of growing up in Italy...the food is divine and the waiters are gorgeous!  The locals eat there in the heart of little Italy...oh and we even got a picture with the Mona Lisa fiat! I wish I could brig the food home with me. Downside-having to walk through China Town to leave.
author: Alice K.

description: You are in Italian-zone on Columbus Avenue! There are lots of great restaurants, but today we chose Mona Lisa. Easily the vest eggplant parm I have ever had. The eggplant was paper thin sliced with mozzarella cheese and am incredible red sauce. Along with a glass of chianti, it was a perfect early dinner. I have leftovers for later too! The fabulous music made for a perfect sitting:  Frank Sinatra, Dean Martin, classic stuff that I love...
author: Donna H.

description: This restaurant is Amazing!! My Husband and I were visiting from Hawaii, we ate dinner here 3 nights in a row!! Maurizio the owner is wonderful and his staff is amazing!! The waiters are from Italy and speak Italian,too.  If Rome is to far for you to visit then just come to Mona Lisa, The menu is extensive especially Parpadelle Porcini! Buonisimo!!The best of all is there flute Lemoncello for desert, the flavor wakes up your palate!!!!
author: jane u.

description: I had pasta with veal. i thought the food was ok. A couple that I went with had the chicken parm and the portion is huge!
author: Kyle W.

description:
continuing with my trend of trying every north beach italian restaurant, some friends and I opted for Mona Lisa after seeing their huge menu selection.  With well over 100 options to choose from, we were bound to find something good, right? well, i kind of wish they had stuck to perfecting a few dishes, rather than offer a million, but I dont think that necessarily diminished the quality of the food.  

we were offered free bruschetta by the man at the door, which was actually quite delicious.  but i felt like the pastas were a litlte uninspired.  i got the four cheese ravioli, and the taste of the gorgonzola was too overpowering.  The sauces were good, but a lot of the pasta options just seemed a little plain.  

I guess the food was enjoyable, but not memorable, so i likely will keep trying the other italian jaunts.  also, it took a very long time to be served, but that wasn't so bad thanks to the good company.
author: Anne Marie B.

description:
Service: Very bad, rude wait staff.
Food Quality: Absolute garbage, excessively greasy, over cooked, rotten.
Price: Way too high for what they serve

I can't imagine how this place stays in business, nor can I imagine anyone who could give a positive rating based on the food (I shudder to think of what else these people eat if they think the food at Mona Lisa is good).  

My wife and I got the worst stomach aches and cramps right after eating here.  Sad thing is, we were only able to eat a few bites it was so bad.  The food was not only greasy, but also had a sour taste as if it had gone bad.  The waiter was a complete jerk after he asked how things were, and we both said our food was greasy and didn't taste very good.  He merely responded by saying that there was nothing wrong with the food, and then he quickly returned with our bill.  

If you think about calling Mona Lisa for reservations, do yourself a favor and don't!  I wish I had looked up the reviews BEFORE going to this dump.  Read the reviews and don't be fooled by the false 3, 4, or 5 star ratings (they were probably written by Mona Lisa employees and their families)
author: Matt S.

description: Good place to take a first date in North Beach. Faux Italian decor and bare breasted Mona Lisa's fill the high ceiling fresco covered walls. Since first dates are usually ones you barely touch your food and your in the courting role of pretending to be interested in conversation you wont even realize your food is average at best. Nice and dark with warm lights give a your date plus 1 automatically because you cant see her. Desert however is worth getting. Anything with hazel nuts are a win.
author: Howard C.

description: Delicious authentic food & spectacular service!! We were sat very quickly & didn't have to wait very long for our food. Crab ravioli yummy ! We will definitely be back!!
author: Elaine R.

description:
I read the reviews, so I decided that this would be the spot for me to go with my girlfriend and her husband. 

I'm not going to bore you (on purpose - LOL). We came, we found parking (a miracle), we ate and we conquered. 

We absolutely loved the shrimp appetizer and hubby had his first try of Risotto. It was love at first bite. 

Definitely worth the drive around the block 10 times looking for parking, before finding public parking garage 3 blocks away (in Chinatown).
author: Bee D.

description: Had a mixed bag of seafood with a pink sauce - absolutely phenomenal!  Great bread, oil, vinegar, good wine.  Service was good and friendly, atmosphere a bit gaudy but fun if you're into that sort of thing. Wonderful place!
author: Patricia P.

description: Just had a wonderful dinner here... Real italian owner, waiters, and good old skool authentic italian food like my Sicilian ma used to make... Huge portions, attentive service, and an entertaining host/ owner made for a great evening... Hearty ravioli, zesty fresh bruschetta, and a perfectly large and flavorful portion of tiramisu were favorites...
author: Santo R.

description: Well it's raining and cold and even after the news sais A major storm is comming our way. Where do we go?  Go to Mona's or to Lisa's ? NO GO TO the Mona lisa at Northa Beacha. We sit outside under the awning under heated lamp. So now I think Nat King Kole...Mona Lisa Mona Lisa... Well Mona Lisa is A nice SONG. Mona Lisa the resaurant is A differant story  Mona Lisa is not A  nice. Mona lisa is nice and great and more. Everything looks good...the people the workers the owners  even me and you look good in there. Don't even put on your makeup if your going there they make you beautifull so who needs make up. Well I can name A few...remember most babies cry after they are born when they finnaly see there mothers some keep on crying for months untill they get used to it. Well Mona Lisa didn't make me cry. Bread with butter untill I saw the olive oil and added the smallest splash of there great vinegar. Here comes Mr. anti pasto and he makes me PATSO so now I feel guilty for that one slice of heaven of bread. Mr. ant pot has Bruchetta,greens,cheese, cold cuts,olives and more and it's served taller than A cheapskates wedding cake. I'm not going to forget we already where served the wine that I would of ordered even before we where seated. Wine is the first thing then we talk eat or eat talk.The wine is great ,like I Bazooka Joe does not know that it cost an arm and A leg to get A good Chianti. The Chianti at the Mona Lisa is the tops and dont think it cost an arm and A leg ...wasan't my fault that we had MORE than A few POPS. I went with Ravioli Pomodoro and loved it. My sister made some of the same and when she wasan't looking I threw it in the back yard and there where dead birds all around it the next day. In fact now that I think about this for years after that there where no more ants comming into the house and the rats even went away. Now we order desert , tirameesue with expresso and  for some cappuchino  and before the bill another round of plain old USA(Americano)cofee except for me I do another EXPRESS- SO. So It's the tops the food is good the service is good the location is good the ambiance is good. I only have one complaint . One complaint. We left to soon.
author: OSEPH E.

description:
Great restaurant! Very well priced for North Beach. Got out of there with 3 entrees, an appetizer salad, a half a bottle of wine and a full bottle of wine for $85 before tip. Not bad at all! The service is good and hostesses are very friendly. My favorite spot in North Beach.

HINT: Park at the police station garage on Powell and Vallejo. Very cheap parking and just a few blocks from the heart of the Italian restaurants. Parking is determined my 2 hours segments . We were there for 3-4 hours and paid $7.50. Not bad for SF!
author: Rachel R.

description: Great restaurant.  Food cooked to expectations.  It was our 10 year marriage anniversary and Mona Lisa was our first date.  Owner was very generous and made us feel very special and welcome.  Great experience!!!
author: Eric D.

description: My wife and I's favorite Italian place in San Francisco. Originally pointed out by a tour guide, it has never disappointed. Dark, intimate and very Italian.
author: Jordan B.

description: Very tasty Italian food!  Some dishes have fairly large portions, others are smaller.  Some of the prices are a bit expensive, others reasonable. There are two seafood pasta dishes that are great deals for ~$16, which come packed with mussels.  Also, the calamari fritti meal is a good deal - lots of calamari with marinara sauce, cooked spinach, and a small side of pasta for about ~$15.  The service is a little slow, even if they are not that busy, but the waiters are friendly and the food is good, which make up for it. The first time we ate here with a large group, they brought us appetizers on the house.
author: Shar M.

description:
My heart aches a little bit for the people who have had negative experiences at Mona Lisa's!!! I've been coming to this restaurant for over two years, and have had a great time with every visit.

My boyfriend and I got pulled in like most people by the owner who stands outside... I just want to give him snaps for always standing outside EVEN when it's ridiculously cold!  That's commitment!  While the owner acted as ringleader pulling our attention, it was the extensive menu that really got us.  Brian (bf) LOVES gnocchi, and most Italian restaurants neglect that style of pasta.  There has to be at least 6 gnocchi options on that menu, and Brian has tried most of them, and enjoying most of them.  Let me just keep it real - he loves the cheesy ones.  He's a cheese man. :)

I've tried out different pastas, and have fallen in love with the lasagna.  I jump back and forth from the veggie and the meat versions.  It's a pretty basic lasagna, and for those seeking 18 different cheeses and lots of different veggies... um, this lasagna is not for you.  It's cheese, meat, and noodle.  The flavors are good, and the plate is ALWAYS hot.  

The service can vary.  That place can get PACKED, so when service gets a little slow we're not surprised.  We're usually not rushing out of there either though - if you're on the go, this might not be the restaurant for you.  I personally love the over-decorated look, and pictures of  "famous" people that haved dined there.  (FYI- if you are a star wars fan, Chewbacca loves that place!) 


The place is "cozy" as someone said earlier, so if you go - try and get a place in the back 1) it's warmer 2) the tables are bigger and not as tight. 

Long story short this place is a staple for me!  Granted I haven't been to a lot of the restaurants on columbus, it has been consistent and always a yummy experience.
author: Melanie l.

description:
First I must warn you, if you aren't prepared for some serious cheese, then don't go here! (No, not cow cheese!!) By cheese I mean terrible Roman art, funny little busts, and cute Italian waiters that call you "Bella." With a name like Mona Lisa, how could it not be incredibly corny? Although I tend to run in horror at anything too touristy in this city (I think this has something to do with the fact that I am forced to take the cable car with many slightly inebriated, overly enthusiastic and often overweight tourists to get up the hill to my apt.), this restaurant always leaves me with the warm and fuzzy feeling of being treated to some true Italian hospitality. 

No one can argue that the food itself isn't authentically Italian. Being a vegan and having been to Italy, I have tried many MANY different restaurants' versions of penne arrabiata, and this place makes a lovely one. The sauce is spicy and rich and flavorful. I like to add mushrooms to give myself a little protein, and they are very nice about this and add big juicy sautéed brown mushrooms. They also have a nice bruschetta. I should mention that the menu is ginormous, as in it has every classic Italian dish and its dog, so creative vegans could probably find many choices. I remember one time they made me a very pleasant Italian bean soup as an appetizer, and I've also had a pasta with eggplant that was yummy.  

Mona Lisa has been my go-to North Beach place for several years, because it's cute and comfy, and there's usually not a long wait. If you temporary let go of your fears of touristy places and enjoy the waiters' adorable Italian accents, you'll surely have a nice time.
author: Jeani H.

description: I really wanted to love this place. The menu has over 300 items. The chicken tasted like it'd been cooked before- very chewy. The food came out within minutes of ordering. That's great if you are starving but a meal should take more than a few minutes to prepare.  My wife's gnocchi was good but avoid the beef jerky, I mean chicken.
author: Jason D.

description:
My family was in town, and after spending hours (yes, really) in the nearby City Lights Books, I developed a serious craving for good Italian... we stopped at Mona Lisa on a whim, and it turned out to be a fantastic choice! We (fortunately) happened to arrive right before the evening rush, so we were seated right away, but by the time we left, the restaurant was packed and there was a line outside. The wait staff is among the most friendly and attentive I've encountered in the whole city (and who doesn't LOVE those Italian accents? Sigh...) 

The pasta is DAMN good. All six of us loved our entrees, and would have gladly tried the dessert if we'd left room. The french bread was okay - a little tough - but my heavenly lasagna more than compensated for the bread. The restaurant is also kid-and-vegan friendly, which is a big plus in our family.

The atmosphere and decor is probably one of Mona Lisa's best qualities, after the authentic (mouth-watering) Italian cuisine: it's cozy and warm, with low lighting and festive Italian music. The walls are covered with frescoes and colorful tapestries, and classic sculptures are situated in all the nooks and crannies. The feeling is definitely intimate, which I absolutely love. All in all, it was one of the best dining experiences I've had in a while!

Cute Italian waiters don't hurt, either ;)
author: Sam S.

description: Delicious Italian food, priced pretty competitively for an expensive city. Ate here twice in one week. Our waiter Mario was polite and friendly, and provided us with top notch service. Very pleasant dining experience.
author: Meg S.

description:
What a frustrating dinner!  First of all, the food was pretty good...probably worthy of four stars.  So why only two stars?  The service!  The 'host' was one of the rudest people that I've ever dealt with at a restaurant....he acted as though he was doing us a favor by putting our name on their list and at one point told one of my friends to wait outside when he was merely checking on our table.

To top things off they added a 20% gratuity to our party of five.  I totally understand adding a tip for a large party but for five people? 

I'm always looking for good Italian and would love to return to Mona Lisa for the food but after the way we were treated this evening?  No thanks.
author: phil h.

description:
North Beach is one of my favorite areas in San Francisco. It reminds me so much of Little Italy in Boston or NYC, or Federal Hill in Providence.

I was walking around with Vic looking to grab a bite to eat when we stumbled onto this place only because of the very large and moderately-priced menu. 

The fried calamari was generous and very flavorful amount, the salads are authentic Italian, and the chicken parmesan is superb. Vic had the cheese ravioli and the chicken marsala. I also took two of my co-workers here during a late shift at the office. I also met my friends Don & John there for lunch and they were pleasantly surprised of just how good the the food is.

The Kitchen cooking area is literally right on the dining room floor so you see where all the cooking takes place. Overall, the environment is extremely friendly, charming and quaint, but I won't lie...having an attractive full-blooded Italian server wait on you is an A+ LOL. Plus Vic definitely enjoys the eye candy hehehehe.

Huge Menu, moderate pricing, delicious authentic Italian as good as it gets, friendly service with a smile, and the owner of the joint greeting you and making you feel welcome : PRICELESS.
author: Joe V.

description: The place had one of the best italian food that I have ever eaten. I'm not a big fan of italian food but this is a place that i would go back to when i am in the S.F. area and craving italian food.  The food is GOOD and the prices are good too. The staff was friendly and attentive. We got there just before the dinner rush. We we left, there was a line outside to get into this place.  I can see why that were waiting.  Good Italian food!
author: James Y.

description:
MUST come here when you're in the area..They have the most amazing staff and when I was there, catered to our every want and need. My family would stay in the bay area for about a week or 2 at a time and Mona Lisa was always on our list of restaurants to visit. There are REAL Italian people running the place so you can expect only authentic dishes. There will be lines here for dinner, but if you make friends with one of the guys inside they will get you in quickly. 
The first time we came here, we made friends with our server, who introduced us to the manager and after that we never had to wait in line to get in again! Not to mention that every time we came, the chef would specially make us his favorite appertivos to taste. Its a great dining experience, just be friendly and you'll get that and 100x back in return!
author: Cristina V.

description: Tourist trap restaurant.  Dinner salad is 11 dollars and soup is 12!  Service was pretty bad.  Ordered a salad and pizza and the waiter asked if we would like the salad first, "sure," we said.  He brings the salad which was below average and then brings the pizza 15 minutes later.  The only problem was he put the pizza order in at the same time as the salad order so when the pizza arrived it had already been sitting out for 15 minutes and was old and cold.  So, why bother asking, just bring all the food at the same then!  Geez,.  And the kicker was that the pizza probably was pretty good if served hot out of the oven. Really some of the worst service I have seen in SF for a while.  Try Caffe Sport or Original Joe's at half the price for an authentic North Beach experience.
author: John M.

description: A very good italian restaurant.  Fun staff (very animated) with great service.  Love their asparagus pasta however I will warn you it is a bit rich.  Good value for the price.
author: Dustin R.

description:
Ive got to say, for a restaurant on Columbus I was quite impressed. 
Last night was one of those evenings that i just needed to be in the sunshine. 
My fella and I wondered down Columbus looking for something that would be decent to just chill, eat and watch the world go by. 

The service was great, we had a little table outside and the waiter checked on us often. I had Manicotti which was delicious with a side order of the spanachi salad  ( a little too much oil on as dressing but apart from that ,,,,,,, great! ). 

Not too pricey - $4 for a beer , $6-8 for a glass of wine and the food reasonable .... nothing in the league of TWO but still a tasty little spot to fill that hungry hole while watching the world go by.
author: Amy W.

description: Delightful little gem of a restaurant, we had the most amazing spaghetti with meat-sauce and meatballs, what is so awesome is the meat sauce contains strips of very tender beef in addition to the usual ground meat, very tasty, the calamari only rates 3 stars for us as it was tough should be cut in thinner rings and done a little crispier, the service was superb, we also enjoyed a delightful tiramisu, we will definately be back,
author: stephanie f.

description:
This shady restaurant "lost" our group reservation for Valentine's dinner (5 people). My friend even called the day before to confirm and things seemed to be in place until we arrived. Other groups were complaining that they too were turned away even though they had made reservations well in advance. 

How can you "lose" so many reservations in favor of 2-tops and have the NERVE to turn away so many people who made reservations in advance?! I didn't get a chance to eat here and was actually looking forward to it, but I won't even bother trying and I'll be telling everyone I know.

We ended up going to DuPont Thai and had a great time.
author: Catherine H.

description:
Okay I'm still not sober.

But I'll still write a review on this place.

1.) Service was okay. I had to pour my own glass of wine.

2.) Alfredo Leonardo. Creamy sauce with fresh tomatoes and chicken breast. Needs more salt, chicken too dry.

3.) At least they gave us free bruchetta.

4.) Chicken marsala. My goodness, they must have used the same exact chicken that was in my alfredo. DRYYYYYYY!!!

I hate chicken breast. I hate DRY chicken breast even more.
author: Nance W.

description:
I've been to this delightful restaurant a couple of times.

The first time was good.  All I really remember was the garlic bread I got.  Well, it was more like garlic with a little bread.  It was extremely strong, yet good.  The next couple of days, I reeked of garlic, but it just kept the vampires away.

The 2nd time I went, I got the spaghetti and meatballs, I know...very adventurous, and it was pretty good.  Good portion size and not too expensive.

The food didn't blow me away, but the service and atmosphere made up for it from one of the hosts playing the trombone to another host asking if we wanted milk for my daughter.
author: Marcus J.

description:
I'll try to keep this short and sweet: MONA LISA IS AMAZING. 

I just recently got back from a two week trip to Greece and Italy, and I have to say, as Mona Lisa is my favorite Italian restaurant, I compared every meal I had in Italy to it. Honestly, very few of them measured up. This may seem like an overstatement, but I'm not kidding. 

From the service to the food to the setting to the location, this is my number one pick of restaurants in San Francisco. I always go for the vegetarian lasagna and bruschetta, and I highly recommend it. 

Thanks Mona Lisa for being such a great place to bring family and friends!
author: Marie L.

description: Come here for the ambiance and decor, a  unique experience. Food is good but I can't say it's significantly better than every other pricey Italian white-cloth restaurant. Service was excellent though.
author: N M.

description:
Eh...  Definitely a neighborhood italian restaurant - decent sized portions, nothing too "foodie-esque".  Some of the food I could've managed to make at home, and some of it  I probably can't...

Huge menu (several pages long) - all with pretty basic food.  

I got something in a cream sauce - and managed to finish about half of it - lacking a little bit of salt.  

Tiramisu was good though!  nice and creamy and sweet :)  Decent sized portion for 2 people to share.

Not altogether dissappointing for the prices, and I'd probably go here if I lived closer (quick service, consistent fare), but I wouldn't go out of my way to go here again.
author: Stephanie P.

description:
I'm originally from SF and I've been going to Mona Lisa for close to 20 years. The food and ambiance are AMAZING . The owner and staff are welcoming and warm. The waiters are are Italian just like the owner which makes you feel like you really are in Italy! From going here when I was single in the early. 90's  to now married with a child my family enjoys  Mona Lisa on SF vacations. We have many fond memories of eating the food and visiting with friends. The owner recognizes my daughter and I when we arrive and brings bruschetta every time! I can't say enough about the food and hospitality. Pastas are homemade and portions are huge. If you were my friend, I would insist that you try it out.

Happy eating!
author: T B.

description:
What can I say?  Sometimes you have that Italian food itch you just have to scratch, and if you're in the neighborhood, Mona Lisa might be the cure.  It's a big menu, so if you have no clue or cravings, then you might be in trouble.  The staple for me in any Italian restaurant is the Chicken Parmigiana.  I finished my plate - so that's good sign, no?

This place is loud, crowded, and the decor is  oh so tacky - but it's fun.  I don't go to North Beach often, only because there are so many less crowded options in the city - but if I'm in that part of town, I wouldn't hesitate to recommend Mona Lisa.
author: Denise M.

description:
North Beach is so full of italian restaurants that I have yet to find a complete favorite.  Went to Mona Lisa with some friends and the food was good/okay. Never really had an urge to go back there right away, but if I end up there for another dinner, I'm sure it'll be decent food.

By the way, theres a lot of nude art around. Now I'm all for the beauty of art, but that much nakedness can tend to be distracting during dinner. LOL.
author: Shafaq C.

description:
I have been to Mona Lisa a few times. It is one of my closest friend's favorite places - so we also go every year on her bday.

Overall, it is average. The service is pretty good but seating is always a pain. Long waits and crowded tables - what sucks is reservations also always require a wait (um so is there even a point to having reservations here? - no.) Prices are good and not a rip like the other North Beach tourists traps (ie Stinking Rose). I'd say that 75% of the staff are actual Italians with real accents - a good percentage compared to other North Beach restaurants.

The food is good for a few reasons - no matter who you bring, they will find something they want to eat. This place has EVERYTHING and they have every pasta combo possible. For example, pene with pesto sauce, pene with alfredo sauce, spaghetti with shrimp in cheese sauce, spaghetti in marinara sauce, etc... 

I always get the Rigatoni Filomena (pasta with artichokes, truffles, garlic and in a butter/oil sauce) because:
1) I am not into tomato sauce anymore
2) Cheese sauce upsets my stomach
3) Pesto gives me gas
4) I love truffles!

They have an average wine list and good desserts too. Tell them if there is a bday - you get tiramisu.
author: Jessica L.

description: Highly overrated place. The service is terrible and we had to call the servers 4-5 times before we could gey their attention. The food was terrible and my pasta was absolutely uncooked. My wife's chicken dish tasted of only garlic and nothing else. Would not recommend this restaurant to any one.
author: Alaap T.

description:
The Location: Great location. It's right in the heart of North Beach where there are lots of things to do. I think its location, for me, might be both it's greatest asset and it's downfall. But we'll get to that momentarily. 

The Service: We were about 6 people and it took them about an hour to sit us down. The host was snobbish, fun, but definitely some one you'd expect to be guarding a treasure of a restaurant. We had to speak to the manager to let us sit on one of the many empty tables outside and drink wine. And drink we did.

The Space: Simply mediocre. Not bad, but nothing impressing. I'm sure a lot of American tourists who deem Italy as ethnic will probably enjoy it. The decoration inside is like a proud Italian-American exploded in there. There are Italian art pieces just about everywhere, and very nice lighting. Almost like Buca Di Beppo with a bigger budget.

The Food: Absolutely mediocre or less. The gnocchi tasted like it had been sitting somewhere forever. The ravioli was from the frozen food section of Trader Joe's. One of the staff, having asked him in his native tongue, even told me the sauces came from cans. I'm not particularly blown away by Italian cuisine, but come on, you can't really be in North Beach and claim to have authentic Italian cuisine, then serve me frozen and canned food. The $30 bottles of wine were also mediocre

The Ambient: Mostly tourists and your daily, every day San Franciscans. A lot of bad dates and awkward silent tables, as well as large dinner parties. I hate to say it, but the people that night were also mediocre. No one looked particularly fabulous and there were large groups of annoying people thinking they were trendy because they were eating in North Beach.

The Veredict: I'm not saying this place is bad. It's just definition of a mediocre restaurant trying to sell itself as a trendy. I guess that was my biggest problem with it; the fact that the servers were well dressed, that the host was very snobbish, that the prices were so elevated and that it was on a main street -- completely over-promising and under-delivering. The canned/frozen food itself was not bad. As a matter of fact I had a tomato and basil that I rather enjoyed and tasted quite fresh. And I am willing to throw down some good money for some good food. But this place was simply too much and not enough.
author: SF N.

description:
Uh-uh-uhhhh, tasty, TASTY!!!   =)~

I LOVE Italian food!!!  I love it!!!!!!!!

Mona Lisa is one of my FAVORITE Italian restaurants and I'm all about taste and flavor!!!  Mmm, good!  Creamy pasta, oh yes....!

I recommend this place to anyone who likes Italian food.  I hate bland Italian.  Okay, so maybe I like "Americanized" Italian...full of flavor and cheese and creamy sauces!!!  Mmmhmm-good!
author: Ladi Da A.

description:
The first time I went, I was ass to ass with another party...not good.  The second time, not so much.  Maybe someone from the health department came in and said they're not allowed to have as many people as they tried fitting into their establishment previously.  Who knows.  I like eating my food with a little bit of elbow room.  Elbow room is good for picking up your food with a fork.  

I like their food too!  At least the couple of dishes that I've tried.  I had the Fettuccine Alfredo with prawns and that was like a happy dance in my tummy.  Sure it was a little oily, but hey- it's Alfredo.  I also tried some chicken thingy with ham and cheese and delicious saucy goodness.  I couldn't tell you what it was called, but it was very yummy.  If I had more than 2 thumbs, I'd hold all of them up.

Since I'm not a high roller, I rarely eat here.  It can be like a punch to a wallets stomach if you eat there fairly often.  But once in a while is alright with me!

The end.
author: Duckie A.

description: Had the lasagna, tasty good sauce and as I ate a cockroach ran up the wall and perched on the top of the frame around the breast exposed Mona Lisa above my table.  The waiter saw me peering at the picture and began to explain the painting to me...I told him that I was looking at the roach on the top.  He quickly got a rag and removed the insect.  In short order the manager came by the table to explain that there was a problem in all of North Beach and that they were so close to Chinatown and that they were sending in teams to check the basements of all the area because of the problem.  During the conversation another roach appeared on cue.  I didn't finish eating, but wasn't charged for the meal.  The management was apologetic and worked for customer recovery which I appreciated.
author: Steve P.

description:
My friend kept ranting and raving about this place so I decided to try Mona Lisa.

We went to dinner with a co-worker of mine after work and while walking by, several men tried to entice us into eating there. It reminded me of the dudes in the New York City streets trying to entice me into trying out their restaurants. I had no idea I was standing right outside of the restaurant. 

Walked inside the restaurant and it was kinda dark...I felt very cramped like everyone was invading my personal space. Hehe....

As a calamari lover, I have to say that I didn't really enjoy their calamari but the portion was great! I ordered the linguini something something in pink sauce...(helpful, aren't I?). I didn't particularly enjoy my pasta dish...maybe because I could taste the marsala wine (or what I thought was marsala wine) more than I could taste the linguini, meat, and mushrooms? I could taste some of the tomatoes. 

The walls of the restaurant were completely covered with paintings...some which were interesting to look at and some I didn't care to look at. Hehe....I kinda felt like I was at church when I looked up at the ceiling.

Their portions are filling but I would have to say that I have tasted better Italian food in my life. I LOVE Italian food but was a little disappointed in this place.
author: V M.

description:
BY FAR one of my favorite restaurants!!

Beautiful place, Good food, and Very Affordable!!
author: Ceebo C.

description: My favorite Italian restaurant I've tried in North Beach. The service was very friendly. Received complementary appetizers. The gnocchi was deliciously made-- homemade-- and the four cheese sauce was very gorgonzola-y. The bread wasn't the freshest but the olive oil and balsamic were high quality. Would definitely eat here again!
author: Lissette L.

description:
Mona Lisa how I love you.....So many pastas to choose from. My favorite is the very basic lasagna. Yummy homemade tasting sauce and lots of cheese. Low lights and lots of people. Real italian waiters and decent service. 

One star deducted for ugly bathroom with long waits and super crowded tables.
author: E. Y. G.

description: We were out with family walking around North Beach and were invited in to eat by a very friendly staff member.  The inside has beautiful murals which we enjoyed.  We felt so comfortable there.  We settled in with a glass of chianti and laughed and enjoyed ourselves until dinner came.  The only sounds heard after that was sounds of pure contentment as we ate a delicious meal accompanied by bread.  The price was reasonable for 5 people.  We will be back!
author: Renee S.

description:
Last night, my boyfriend and I were trying to find a decent place to eat in North Beach around 11pm. I knew of the ones on the main drag like Cafe Figaro and Calzones, but they were packed with too many people. We finally settled on Mona Lisa. Bad idea.

First thing I noticed was the horribly cheesy and colorful decor on the inside and out. We were seated quickly next to a window by an almost too friendly server. He was a bit weird....just kind of leered at us the whole time. I took my hair and covered my cleavage when he left our table. 

Their menu consisted of an extensive list of pasta dishes ranging from $11 to $18. I was feening for some good gnocchi and so I ordered the Gorgonzola Gnocchi with Spinach and Walnuts. The bf decided on the Crab Ravioli. Soooo not worth $16.95 each. No flavor or quality whatsoever. My gnocchi tasted like old cheese. Yack.

But maybe it was our fault for trying to find a good place to eat at 11pm? Hell no. That's no excuse for a restaurant.
author: Anne E.

description:
I promised myself that I would go here by the end of the summer and I did. I saw it on my way to another restaurant and made it my business to drag my mom, her friend, my friend, and my mom's friend's daughter to this place... I think it was worth it. 

The bruschetta and the other appetizer came very quickly, but the actual food didn't. My friend got some sort of soup, my friend's mom got gnocci (which I tried), her daughter got some salad (looked boring), and I got pasta with peas and alfredo sauce (waited like 3 weeks to get this).  Mine was very good. It took a while for it to come because I remember being sorry that I filled up on the appetizers but it was a lovely evening. The gnocchi was really good too! My friend and I split a cannoli for dessert. It was good too. 

However, the menu was too long. Ramsay is right, it's better to have fewer items on a menu and have those items be perfect than to have too much. Mona Lisa had way too many things on their menu. It was annoying and confusing and I didn't know what to get for quite a while. Then, their dessert menu (though I am not usually a huge fan of dessert at restaurants to begin with) was tiny! Unbalanced!

The lighting was dim. Being my pet peeve, this bothered me.

Even though it was busy, we got seated right away. I wouldn't have wanted to sit outside though because it was so cold that night. But it was a really nice end to the summer. I am really glad I went I think.
author: Clare R.

description: The meatballs for apps were really good. And that's where it ends. The wait at Franchino was close to two hours and we were starving. That, combined with the packed house (full of tourists) at Mona Lisa is the only reason we walked in. The unabashedly craptastic carbonara is the reason we'll never be back. Next time I'll bring a folding chair, wear flats and bring a fiber bar and post up at Franchino.
author: Vanessa Y.

description: I love the food there. Five star also for their service that they let us sit in a mini-car for dinner ~~ Soooo cuteeeee!!!
author: Jingwan L.

description:
Some talkative stranger at a cafe told me this was the best Italian food in North Beach.  At the time, I ignored him.  Later I sort of stumbled into it, so I decided to go there with some out of town friends.  I really wasn't expecting much because I am so tired of all the crappy North Beach Italian places with the same menu and mediocre food, but I was too hungry to keep looking.  

I ate here during off hours, and my group were the only Americans- everyone else eating there was Italian!  Two of the three of us tried the gnocchi (it's homemade) and it was SO GOOD.  The third person had a mixed seafood pasta that he said was really good, but I didn't try it so I can't speak for that.  I would definitely come back here for more gnocchi.  *They also gave us free bruschetta.
author: Erin D.

description:
The selection was EXTENSIVE! You will definitely need to take your time going through the menu--you will not be disappointed!

I ordered a simple spaghetti carbonara and was immediately impressed. The flavor was on point, not overly creamy (why other "Italian" restaurants think it's supposed to be is beyond me).

I will agree with almost all the posts that the customer service totally exceeds any restaurant I've ever been to--period! I went there on a Friday night with a bunch of friends for a birthday.First of all: the seating host was just too frikkin cute with an adorable Italian accent to boot, I'm definitely NOT complaining about that; I don't remember your name but if you're reading this you are H-O-T! Come to think of it, almost their entire staff was comprised of men, yes ladies, cute men! And the owner was just so welcoming and completely speaking to me in Italian like we were old pals (I'm an American born Asian mind you, which means I can barely speak my own language =P).

Overall: food was great, energy was awesome and eye candy was abundant--enjoy!
author: Jan D.

description:
I had a fantastic meal here which was just perfect from the beginning to end. We didn't have dinner reservations which was not a problem. We were quickly seated and were fortunate to get a small table in the corner by the front window. We started with the Antipasto misto which had some prosciutto and other fine thinly sliced deli meats along with superb cheese and olives. Of course, with it being Little Italy and so many great delicatessens in the area I would not expect any less. I ordered the homemade ravioli de lagosta (lobster-stuffed ravioli) covered in a divine creamy tomato sauce. My boyfriend was equally pleased with his salmon in tomato cream sauce with shrimp. It just all had us moaning in delight at our table. We were celebrating both our birthdays with this meal so they brought out a tiramisu with a candle. I'm not really a fan of tiramisu but I promise you this was one of the most delicious desserts I have ever enjoyed. Perhaps I've just never had good tiramisu before and now I've been schooled. 

There was nothing bad about that meal except that it ended.
author: Patricia S.

description: Mona Lisa restaurant is so authentic you feel like your at home. I'm from sf and come here all the time native local and food fanatic. Mona Lisas is always fresh and ur welcomed with a smile every time you walk through the door. Manga!!!
author: Stacy P.

description:
As a general foreward to this preview of an Italian restaurant in North Beach, I've been a bit put off by the fact that now, outside every one of these little restaruants/cafes (it seems) they have these people outside hard selling their restaurant and almost seeming like they're forcing you to go in!  What the hell?  I don't remember them ever having these people, but then again I haven't been to NB in a while...

Anyways, Mona Lisa is the standard kitschy italian place which interesting decor, but seriously, ass to ass (agreeing with daphne a.!).  It's a small place I realize, but again, do we have to be buttcheek to buttcheek with the burly wurly man sitting next to us?  The menu of course, is HUGE, however, I thought it was a bit distracting and not really specialized...I'd rather have a smaller, more interesting menu than a HUGE menu of different variations of the same thing....it took me forever to read over it, and I finally picked one just because I didn't want to keep the waiter waiting FOREVER. 

I tried: 

Salmon with Olive oil and capers - my main dish, it was pretty darn good, nice simple flavor, but i thought it could have come with a bit more pasta and spinach, especially since the total bill came out to 72 dollars...

Seafood Risotto - This looked really good and the risotto was a good consistency; big portion and nice that they didn't skimp on the seafood either...
 
Italian Sampler (Bruschetta, mozerella and tomato, and roasted garlic) - I liked the Sicilian Candy (roasted garlic) and the bruschetta was nice and clean with tons of tomato like i Like it, the mozerella however was really salty  but in general the portions were good....

The service was nice, but after a while the waiter was a bit annoying...because we waited at least 20 minutes for the bill...however it wasn't shoddy...which is good...

In general I'd give this place a 3; overall might be good for tourists and I think the main target is tourists since they're on a main thoroughfare.  the decor was nice, the food was standard, the service was pretty good, all in all a 3star experience

one word of advice though, don't come here for a date, since it can get a bit LOUD....
author: Linda C.

description:
So I'm really torn about whether to give this place two or three stars.  I settled on three because I can imagine myself eating here again, but I'm not necessarily sure whether I want to.

I'll start with the positives.  Every time I've been here, the servers have been very friendly and accommodating.  Having worked in a restaurant before, I know how difficult this can be, especially when you work in a touristy area.  So the service itself in terms of the servers' attitude gets five stars.  The location is also great, and it's a fun atmosphere inside.  Four stars on that front.

Now on to the negatives.  This place is crowded.  Ridiculously so.  And it doesn't feel like a scene.  It feels like a crowded tourist trap.  There also tend to be annoyingly loud groups of people eating here.  The reason I don't really like this place is its other patrons.  If they would just stay home, then I'd give this place four stars.  The other negative is the time it takes to get your food.  The first few times I ate here, we got our food pretty quickly.  The last two times?  Wow, it took forever.  The servers were very apologetic about this, so that was good, but I can't eat apologies, so the wait time definitely gets one star.

The food itself?  It's OK.  Anywhere from three to four stars depending on what you order.
author: John S.

description: My mother and I went here twice during her visit to SF and we both loved it both times! The main courses and appetizers we ordered and the wine and drinks/dessert were always good. When I want Italian food, this is where I'll probably return. The food is authentically Italian and run by Italian immigrants. It's a also in a great area to do tourist things or shopping.
author: Matthew P.

description:
My family and I dined here for mom's birthday. Food is good, but nothing extraordinary or stands out from the other Italian restaurants in North Beach. 

The gnochhi was cooked nicely, but the sauce I had it in (on the creamier side) made the dish too heavy. Desserts were pre-made, but still good. Some nice twists with gelato and fruit. 

Mom got a free t-shirt also, so come here on your birthday for the freebie.
author: Teresa Y.

description:
I chose to eat here for my birthday lunch, because I always pass by this restaurant on my way to work all the time. It's definitely a beautiful restaurant to admire from the outside and inside. The art and style of this place inside is really niiicceee. 

When I came to eat here, there weren't a lot of people. There were only like 3 or 4 small tables occupied in a cramped vicinity by the window. I don't like how my friend and I were seated along with the other groups in the restaurant in just one small side of the restaurant. I guess I understood why, but it didn't feel all that comfortable. 

Other than that, I think I would like to come here again and try something else on the big menu they have. There's a lot to choose from so it's hard to decide.
