I've only tried one dish and it was quite decent. The food comes in good proportions!
author: Bets Y.

description:
This place has so many different risotto dishes, that there's an entire section for it on the menu! LOVE THE RISOTTO! So far i've only been able to try two of them:

Risotto Sciolligo - seafood risotto in white wine sauce

AND

Risotto Pescatore - seafood risotto in tomato sauce

Adventurous aren't I? Either way, both dishes are great, and i'm definitely planning on coming back and trying more of them, i haven't even looked at the pizza or pasta on the menu yet.

Also, this place truly truly has an italian feel to it, everyone from the host outside (who i swear was named, vinny, or tony) to our waiter (who i also swear was named vinny, or tony) was honest-to-goodness certified italian.  This is the kinda place, i would expect to see tony soprano hanging out in the back! MONA LISA'S ROCKS!
author: Linh T.

description:
One of these stars is definitely attributed to the fact that myself and my 2 coworkers had one of the coveted outside tables that has a heat lamp above. Being outside, people watching, and eating dinner is one of my fave things ever, but doing it while not freezing my ass off is way better!!

The food was delicious actually. I had an arugula salad and got spaghetti with arribiatta sauce. I ate every single last bite of both (I was hungry too, though). My coworkers both enjoyed their food as well. The pasta was cooked wonderfully, al dente as it should have been.

The wine was OK. I was a bit disappointed to not see wine that was 'of value' (read: cheaper). 

Service was good too; even though we had a prime table, I didn't feel we were rushed at all.
author: Purvi R.

description:
Looking for a spot to take the out of towners in Little Italy? Mona Lisa is the place. Sure you can go for the infamous tourist trap aka The Stinking Rose (btw, they have one in Beverly Hills too) or the one of the Steps of Rome (they all look the same to me) but if you want true to form Italian. Italian that captures all your senses not just your palette, grab your visitors and head over to Mona Lisa. Once we walked in my brain resurrected the word, gaudy, but in a good way. From the paintings on the wall, the Italian music blaring loudly, to the Italian servers, all gaudy, all fun!

I must say I am not a professional foodie, so I cannot distinguish from various regions in Italy but I do love pasta cooked to perfection and Mona Lisa fits the bill. The group of us ordered throughout the menu: Black Ink Squid Spaghetti, Pizza, Salmon Risotto, Penne Bolognese, and Fettucine Mona Lisa, all very tasty and seasoned just right. It was also refreshing to see the chef prepare our meals in the front and serve them all at the same time in their piping hot, steam rising to hit your face w/the smell of garlic glory.

And after you finish your meal, take a glimpse at the Mona Lisa painting displayed in the center of the restaurant. Is she or isn't she smiling? Hmm, I'm certain your belly will tell you the answer.
author: Cecile Q.

description:
This is one of those times I'd really like to give 3.5 stars.  On the one hand, my food was incredible (gorgonzola gnocci) and the glasses of wine were enormous.  Also, it's a huge place so we got seated immediately even though it was a Thursday night and we arrived right at dinnertime (around 8pm).  I also really liked the olive oil and balsamic right at the table for bread.

However, my friend's food was only decent (seafood risotto- essentially just lots of kinds of seafood on top of some soggy rice with marinara sauce on it, not risotto at all) and the service was terrible.  Our waiter came to our table exactly twice- once to take our order and once to give us our bill- and after eating a big portion of very rich food, all I wanted was some water that never came.  Ever.  He seemed pissed from the start when I showed him that I had a $25 Restaurant.com gift certificate, which confused me because he was guaranteed an 18% tip on the full bill (one of the conditions of the certificate) so it wasn't like we were going to give him a lousy tip because we had a gift certificate.  The food also took over 30 minutes to come out which isn't a big deal but I guess I just expect some communication from the server if food is going to take a long time.  And some water.  Please.  

All in all, my experience was tainted.  However, I don't like to judge a place by one bad server- maybe his dog died that day, who knows- so I will be lured back by the huge glasses of wine and the good dinner I ate at some point and I'll let you know how it goes.
author: Luthien N.

description:
menu:  it concerns me when a restaurant (whose name is not cheesecake factory) has an extremely large menu.

decor:  the carpets are in dire need of a deep clean.  maybe it was just a dead tuesday night, but i felt like i was walking into the beginning of an episode of kitchen nightmares.

staff:  very friendly, but careless.

food:  average.  flavors are not spectacular, nor are they something to complain about.

one star story:  i ordered risotto and was served a huge plate of seafood.  a minute or two after receiving the dish, I realized that there had been a mistake (my fault, since i was busy chatting with a friend).  anyways, i hadn't touched the food and waved the waiter over to let him know.  he remembered my original order, apologized, and took the wrong plate back.  He returned immediately carrying three plates:  one for me (the correct order) and two for the table behind me (one of which was the exact same plate he had just taken from me).  i couldn't believe that he had reused the same plate.  i'm not sure if the patrons behind saw what happened, but i overheard complaints that the seafood was ice cold.  they refused an offer to "reheat" the dish and sent the plate back.  the waiter returned a few minutes later offering to fire a new order, to no avail.
author: Clara H.

description:
My baked cheese ravioli was alright, but it wasn't anything special. The complimentary bread didn't help, either. It was just average. The lighting was also really strange that night. Kind of green, which may or may not have made my pasta sauce taste vaguely like spaghettios. 

Next time I'm going to Panta Rei.
author: Dave K.

description:
Came  here for a late lunch today with my coworkers--so the restaurant was almost completely deserted.  We ordered a couple Peronis to start with, and that's where the fun began.

The calimari we got as appetizers was great, they were fairly large, had just the right amount of breading, and the marinara sauce was mouth watering.  One dish was enough to momentarily satisfy our hunger, since it was 2:30pm and I hadn't eaten since 6:30 that morning--combined with the wonderful bread and vineager/olive oil.

The dish I ordered was a chicken..something or other, which came with spinach, pasta, and a chicken with ham and mozerella.  The pasta was perfectly cooked, the spinach was amazing, and the chicken/ham/cheese combo was just perfect.

All in all it was a great meal in a location not too far from my office.  The service was good, and the overall atmosphere made for a very satisfying experience.  Highly recommended.

/the above was written while slightly buzzed after a long trip to the "pub" afterward, so take that into consideration :)
author: Tien N.

description:
I joined Yelp just to write a review on Mona Lisa Restaurant. Don't we all have a story like this one? A terrible dining experience that you just need to share, so you join yelp, like you've been saying you would do for months.

Anyway - on to the story. A friend and I picked Mona Lisa somewhat randomly as we strolled through North Beach. The manager at the door was friendly and sat us at an outside table, under a heat lamp. So far so good. After about 5 minutes, bread was brought over - without butter or oil or anything. I tasted it. It was incredibly stale. Another 5 minutes, and we were able to flag someone down to get some butter and oil... at least that covered up the stale taste.

Finally, after another 10 minutes, we ordered. In retrospect, it took forever to even order, but at the time my friend and I were chatting, so it wasn't a big deal. I ordered veal parmigiana and she ordered pasta with salmon. We ordered a ceasar salad to split. Two pretty easy dishes. Around this time, two women sat next to us and, about 10 minutes later, they ordered too. (One of them also ordered the veal parm).

10 minutes or so go by and our salad comes - we split it, it's fine. Nothing to write home about. Way too much dressing. Another 20 minutes go by. Nothing. Finally, we see our waiter coming outside with two plates.... which he puts down on the table next to ours, where the women sat over 20 minutes after us, and were still eating the salad they were splitting.

At this point, I was getting upset. I tried to get the manager's attention, but he was busy taking pictures with tourists. Finally, our waiter came back out to give parmesan cheese to the table next to us, and when I told him it had been ridiculously long since we ordered, he said "it's coming!" and stormed off. Another 8 minutes went by, and still nothing (and no waiter with an update), so I went to the manager. He was flustered, pointed to the waiter, and finally got the waiter's attention. The waiter was downright rude. RUDE! He was visibly upset that I'd gone to his manager over him.

I went back outside and like magic, our food came out within moments. Something makes me think it was sitting out for quite some time. The waiter started yelling at me for going to the manager and that "the rest of the restaurant needs their meals too, so be patient." I was appalled and just said that we waited over 45 minutes for our food, and that's absurd in a restaurant like theirs.

The manager came over a minute later and apologized, saying the waiter had "too much stress." Quite frankly, I don't care how stressed he is. His job is to make my meal nice and uneventful. I was pissed. The manager apologized profusely, as did a female waitress who came out a minute later to check on us - it seemed she was the only sensible one in the place.

The food itself was blah. The veal may or may not have been very thinly pounded chicken - it had that consistency. It was hard to tell for sure because it was smothered in tasteless sauce and parmesan cheese. I wasn't a fan. Friend liked her salmon pasta, but was also pissed at the service.

The manager tried to right the wrong by giving us a free tiramisu. It was pretty tasty, and showed he cared about his customers, at least. That jerk of a waiter, on the other hand...

I won't return. Ever.
author: Dan L.

description:
I really don't understand the appeal of this restaurant. I went for a birthday dinner last weekend and had to wait an hour for a table even though we had a reservation. 

When we were finally seated, I sat down on a broken water glass on my chair! I actually had to pull a huge shard of glass out of my ass, leaving a nice bloody puncture wound! It wasn't very big, but it was deep and was still bleeding that night when I went to bed. Our waiter was really apologetic and gave us extra appetizers that we didn't order, but it would have been much nicer to have the meal comp'd, especially since the food was pretty bad. I really could have done without the free out of season melon and prosciutto and the soggy bruschetta. 

I ordered the eggplant parmesan because I figured anything with cheese is usually pretty good, but this wasn't even very good in a white trash kind of way. The sauce was okay, but there was really more breading than anything else. I really had to take a leap of faith to believe that there was any eggplant buried in the sticky floury muck that was surrounding it. The "eggplant" came with a side of penne with marinara that was actually inedible (how hard it is to do a decent red sauce?!) and sauteed spinach that was nearly inedible (again - really hard to get wrong). 

As far as I could tell, the only thing this restaurant has going for it is a polite, attentive waitstaff, but it's hard to know if they would have been as polite and attentive if I hadn't been speared in the ass with a large shard of glass.
author: Caitlin L.

description: My wife, myself, and my best friend were in town from Chicago, and being Italian, I always make sure to check out the Little Italy of any town I'm visiting.  We stumbled on Mona Lisa while looking for a place to eat.  The owner and one of the employees were standing in front speaking Italian and I jumped right into the conversation.  The owner turned out to be Sicilian like myself, so we talked for a while.  It was the start of an amazing evening.  They sat us and immediately the food began to come.  Antipasto, Calamari fritti, Shrimp, fresh bread with olive oil.  Then we ordered our entrees and it was also great.  The sauce was flavorful, the pasta 'al dente', the zuppa di pesce was super fresh!  I recommend this place, not only for the food, but also for the quality of people who work and own this wonderful establishment.  I felt like I was eating at a family members house and for me, that is the ULTIMATE compliment.
author: Michael S.

description:
Open late like so many little places in North Beach, this place was still packed at 11pm! The service was quick and attentive and the decor was interesting but not distracting. We asked for a table near the windows in the front since our favorite pastime is watching the characters in North Beach; we were not disappointed on this Saturday night, always the siren screeching down Columbus or the drunk bachelorette partygoers staggering in and out of traffic or the sweet-looking old couple strolling after a late dinner. What a great neighborhood! And Mona Lisa has been one of the best meals in the neighborhood! 

No appetizers, buy the bread and olive oil were yummy. We had the mozzarella risotto and spaghetti carbonera, both filling and satisfying. Ice tea was great, too. 

It was a quick experience, but another one we hope to have again soon.
author: Fernando C.

description:
Blech. 

This place is a "TOURIST TRAP" to the extreme.  They are robbing people blind, with their EXTREMELY over-priced, un-original, bland, tasteless, less-than-mediocre Italian fare.  

In fact, it is actually kind of sad to me to see that some people have given such high scores to this restaurant--it doesn't speak very well of their knowledge (sorry) of GOOD Italian food.   

Because this restaurant offers up the exact opposite.  

I would have rather paid to eat dog food.
author: Andrea G.

description:
At first I was a bit skeptical about this restaurant, yet once we sat down and looked at the variety of pastas on their menu I knew we would love it. 

I took my boyfriend here for his 25th birthday.  He wanted Italian, with a casual feel.  this place is nice because you can dress up or not dress up and not feel out of place.  They have the largest variety of pasta dishes i have ever scene in one restaurant! They don't have much of a selection of glasses of wine, they do it more on the bottle standpoint, but their reisling was amazing!

I ordered penne alfrado with spinach and chicken, needless to say it was wonderfully tasty! Took the rest home for lunch today! My bf got their Napolatana pizza, which he thought was also really good.  its not the kind of pizza you would find in Italy, being that the crust is still doughy.

The service was good.  The waiter seemed to pay a bit more attention to the older adults(but we always get this kind of treatment! when does it stop we're both well over 23?) anyways my only complaint is that I SPECIFICALLY told the host when I called for reservations that it was my bf's 25th birthday and if they could sing or do something. So the entire dinner I looked forward to it.  yet after we ordered dessert, they never did ANYTHING!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! I WAS SO PISSED. my bf was happy bc he doesn't like to be embarassed, yet it was the principle of it. needless to say it was effected in the tip.

but if its not a bday celebration i would def reccomend this restaurant. 

oh and their dessert menu is to die for! they have a ton of options!
author: kristen l.

description:
I have never yelped in my life, but this restaurant was SO BAD I have to let people know.  

It was a nice night so my boyfriend and I sat outside.  Took the waiter almost 20min to even take our order and he was so rude! We order the roasted garlic for an appetizer and it was disgusting! Tasted like it had been made days earlier. Dinner was not any better, my boyfriend had a whole uncleaned shrimp in his pasta.

By far this is the worst restaurant I have even been to.  Stay away!
author: Stephanie P.

description:
Mona Lisa is BY FAR my favorite Italian restaurant on Columbus Street. BY FAR. I have tried nearly every other Italian joint on the block, and still Mona draws me back every time with her charm and authentic Italian feel.

Why I love Mona Lisa:

The interior is CHARMING! Fresco's and statues everywhere - even "Creation" from the Sistine Chapel on the ceiling! You could easily sit in Mona Lisa for hours and still have new art or fun add-ons to examine. Plus the staff has some great stories of pictures of the boss and famous Italian athletes hanging by the front door. 

The menu is HUGE! Plan on spending at least 10 whole minutes just reading through the whole thing! You name the kind of pasta and sauce - they've got it!

The food is DELICIOUS! I have eaten here at least a dozen times and have always walked away full and satisfied! Everything from the fish dishes (husband's favorite) to the squash ravioli to the pesto fettuccini - delicious! Plus there is always the Italian bread and cold butter to hold you over while you wait!

The wine menu is VAST and full of great, authentic Italian wines. Try the house Pino. They even have have Italian beers!

Best of all, the staff and waiters are - overall - Italian, and even wear Mona Lisa ties. They love chatting with you about all that is Italy (maybe their chats are flirts, maybe I am overly friendly, too - who knows!). 

Seriously, maybe they should hire me to promote the place. 

Everyone's experience at any restaurant will yield different opinions and persuasions. I know some people don't favor Mona because of a long wait in line or at their table. In all my experiences, I have also had to wait anywhere from 0-5 minutes for a table, and 20-45 minutes for food. BUT that's the type of restaurant ML is - a sit-down-and-relax-for-awhile kind of place!

So... go to Mona Lisa if you enjoy authentic-ish Italian food; you have guests in town and want to show them a good time; you are on Columbus Street/Little Italy and want a drink or dessert; you have a few dollars to spare for quantity and quality; you love fresco's and catchy Italian art/statues; you enjoy watching Italian men (young and old) prepare and serve food.

Don't go to Mona Lisa if: you are in a hurry; you are on a tight budget; you are indecisive (the menu will scare you!).
author: Christyn K.

description:
The location right along Columbus is perfect. Mona Lisa has a true Italian feel in both food and interior decorating. The walls and ceiling are done in true rococo and the kitchen is open behind a half-wall.  

The menu offered a huge selection of different dishes and the food itself was excellent. The fare was exceedingly both fresh and flavorful. 

The only downside to this restaurant is the high price.
author: Charles B.

description: We came here for a bite after walking around coit tower, and I wasn't too impressed with the overall experience. It was a very touristy type of place, and very tacky. The food was the only thing that made me add a star to my review. Other than that, I've had better....
author: Nantas S.

description:
This is HANDS-DOWN the BEST service I have ever received at a restaurant! 

Getting that out of the way....the boy and I went on a Friday night and we were seating promptly upon entering, no wait. I used to live in North Beach, and I'd always wanted to try the joint out, but I didn't really have anyone willing to splurge on Italian (something about it being easy to make...) and it can be a bit pricey to dine here. 

The only problem I had was choosing what to eat! The menu is HUUUUUUGE, so MUCH to choose from! We stared at the menu for half an hour before we could just pick something from the five that we had whittled it down to! We got bruchetta for an appetizer (less crunchy, more-chewy, sorta sweet...I enjoyed a great deal, very basil-y, very tasty) and we each got a glass of white wine. The Pinot Grigio was great (sweet, but not too sweet) and the server had several recommendations on what we should try. He got the Chardonnay, which I felt was very strong, super-dry....but he enjoyed.

For entree, I got the Rissotto el Salmone. (Salmon Rissoto...am I butchering these spellings or what!?! haha) It was EXACTLY what I wanted. The salmon was PERFECT and the portion was MASSIVE. I took home half of my food, and I don't typically do that. He got the Scampi del Golfo (Prawns in marsala sauce with mushrooms). His was much-stronger with the herbs; both plates were AMAZING! Our compliments to the chef!

Our server was amazing. He was a doll, keeping up filled on water and checking on us when necessary. The boy had to use the restroom and when he asked about it, our server informed him there was an issue with the restroom, but then proceeded to take him outside, next door, then WAIT for my boyfriend to finish in the bathroom (server waited outside) then escorted him BACK to the restaurant. Above-and-beyond, for sure.

We didn't have room for dessert, but I'm sure it's excellent. 

The interior of this place is super-cute. Very posh, very unique. 

It's a shame a lot of people brand this place "TOURISTY"....but it's GOOD food! GREAT service! I would recommend it to anyone; maybe that's why it has such a great reputation.

(Side note: my boyfriend forgot his hat there and didn't realize it until way later that night. He called up and they had it there for him. He was able to just come in the next day to grab it!)
author: Danyell K.

description:
Mona Lisa is hardly a masterpiece.  This place ranks near the bottom of good italian restaurants in North Beach.

I had the Lasagna di casa, It was supposed to be lasagna in a meat sauce. The dish was mainly sauce and melted cheese, Not a trace of ricotta, nor italian sausage. I would call this dish Lasagna soup.

My wife had Ravioli al Quattro Fromaggi, It was very rich, she could only eat about half of her serving. The cheese was also pungent. Almost as strong as blue cheese.

My daughter had risotto, It was okay, undoubtably the best dish on the table.

I seriously doubt I will ever come back to Mona Lisa. There are too many better options in North Beach. One more note, The food was very salty, We were all dying of thirst about 30 minutes after our meal.
author: Wayne P.

description: The penne bolognese was decent but rather salty and too hot (temperature).  I kept burning my mouth.  Anyhow, the bigger issue is that it cost over $20 for me to get this simple pasta dish for lunch.
author: Niniane W.

description: Nice decor, good service, tasty food.  I liked the old film they had playing in the background.  I'll be back!
author: Madigan M.

description:
We are native San Franciscans.  My wife is from a huge Sicilian family and we LOVE this place. We have been steady customers for 10 years and we have never had a bad meal or bad service here.  You can get great service and a piping hot plate of excellent pasta here on a walk-in at 11:30 P.M. on a weeknight.  Beef carpaccio and Chianti is a good choice to start with.  Always fresh and tasty.

The place looks like a tourist trap with all of the statues (Beethoven??) but it is not.  Have the Ravioli de Zucca (pumpkin) it's insanely good.  The house lasagna is fantastic too.  Last week I had the Osso Bucco on polenta for the first time. It was fall off the bone tender with a deep, complex sauce.  (the polenta was too runny, but I will let them slide this time). The portions are big.

The real Italian wait staff is really busy, but if you smile and are patient on a busy night you will be well taken care of.  

TRY IT!!! YOU'LL LIKE IT!!!
author: Mike G.

description:
Alot of money for tourist grade Italian food. Capresse salad was pathetic 5 tomatoes and a bit of cheese 12.00 
Much better quality to be had in north beach.
author: Mark S.

description:
Mona Lisa is one of those restaurants in North Beach that I always walked by but never went into. Sad I hadn't done it sooner. I've been back twice this month! 

Great selection of standard italian fare (try like 60 choices), a uniquely italian vibe, and great bread (always the test).

I love italian, I live in North Beach, and this place is definately worth your time.
author: Dave M.

description:
I have to disagree with Frankie L. This is nowhere near the best Italian food in SF. But it isn't the worst either.

I've been dying to go because they have these wonderfully tacky illuminated grapes draped all over the outside of the restaurant. I thought it looked kinda fun. The inside was just as crazy as the outside -- kinda like a demure Bucca di Beppo -- complete with poorly executed renditions of famous paintings all over the walls and on the ceiling.

The food was so very average. But what can you expect from a restaurant that literally has almost every Italian dish you've ever heard of on their menu? They don't specialize in anything in particular...which means nothing in particular is spectacular. Nothing was bad though. I finished my meal and thought, "eh, I'm not hungry anymore."

The prices are pretty good though. My boyfriend and I each had an entree and shared half a bottle of chianti and the bill was less than $50. Not bad. And the service was good. 

It's pretty much a tourist trap. And with all the million other Italian places in North Beach to try, I don't think I'll go back anytime soon.
author: Hallie H.

description:
On a whim, we picked this place and boy did we score!  The food was great, we only had to wait about 5 minutes for a table.  The host and staff were gracious.  The Italian sampler was divine and the chicken parm was a great piece of chicken and was tender and perfect.  

I didn't give 5 stars because the tables were a bit cramped which was part of the ambience, but didn't leave you a lot of room to stretch out after your hearty meal.

It was the best meal on this trip to SF.
author: Erik K.

description:
I came here Sunday night for dinner with a friend after a day of exploring the city. I didn't really have any expectations of the restaurant as I'd not heard of it before or read anything before I set foot inside.

The first thing you notice is the absolute overwhelming decor which covers every wall and space of the ceiling with a Sistine Chapel motif.

Sitting down I found the waiter to be attentive, although I noticed throughout the evening that none of the staff or anyone we had interaction with ever smiled or seemed very happy. You sort of got the feeling people weren't too happy to be working, but were treating you well regardless if that makes sense. I'll emphasize though we had no trouble with the service and it does not impact my rating here.

The food itself was a bit of a disappointment. I suppose I should have been suspect given the menu is absolutely enormous, which is always a warning that quality is going to suffer (Haven't restaurants figured out giant menus are a mistake yet? It's 2009)

We opted for Fried Calamari to start off with. While the portions were excellent the friend coating was so thick it was like something from a carnival. They were tasteless as well and needed the dipping sauce to cover it up. Someone on staff needs to learn how to make proper fried calamari-it's not hard. Lightly coated-lightly fried.

The Chicken Saltimbocca I ordered was delivered lukewarm and was not very good. I don't think the chefs are tasting anything they are making. The pasta was incredibly overcooked! You'd have to leave it in 30 minutes to accomplish what I got. The food (if delivered hot) is what I would expect from an Italian take-out place that charges $10. Not bad-just not worthy of a quality restaurant.

Perhaps I got them on a bad night, so I'm still going to award them 3 stars for a fun atmosphere and solid service.  But the food was disappointing.They're charging some solid prices for food that is very mediocre. I don't mind spending money on quality, but I feel foolish rewarding mediocre food with my money. Style over substance for me.
author: David G.

description: Ordered pesto lasagna. Sounds great in theory but it was bland (no salt, no spice) and drowning in cheese and oil. Great if you like greasy; terrible otherwise. Service was very average. Skip this place unless there's a long line at other Italian restaurants in the area and you need to eat ASAP.
author: Sofia T.

description:
I LOVE this place.  I love the fact that they have every sort of pasta and every sort of sauce in the world.  They will make whatever you want easily.  Also, I am a veggie and they never give me that, "What do you mean you don't want meat look?"

I took off a star for it being cramped.  Otherwise, this place is awesome!
author: Lauren R.

description:
THE QUEST FOR ITALIAN STYLE PIZZA

I just got back from Italy -- I was in Aviano, a small Air Force Base town outside of Venice -- where I just fell in love with the everyday, thin, chewy, juicy pizzas we had at the local restaurants there. Every time I look at photos of those pizzas, I crave them, so I just HAD to find something comparable here in SF.

WHY WE DECIDED TO TRY IT...

My husband and I picked Mona Lisa because after walking all over North Beach and looking at menus, we saw the menu at Mona Lisa and were like, "That's it!" -- the menu was exactly the same style that every place we ate in Italy used: A book-style tome with pages and pages of pastas and pizzas. Ok it wasn't QUITE as long as the Italian menus, but there were the characteristic, 10 varieties of every pasta listed one after the other.

HOW IT COMPARED...

When we got the pizza, it was right on (except for the fact that they sliced it, which no Italian restaurant did).

The crust on these pizzas was thin but not like Amicis or California Pizza Kitchen stone-fired thin/crispy crusts are. It was thin and chewy. It was almost like a really fat tortilla only softer if that makes sense.

They didn't have half as many topping options as Italian places did (no horse meat or french fries), although they had more choices than a lot of North Beach places do, but the pizza we got -- La Capital, with pancetta, fresh tomatoes, and added mushrooms -- was quite savory. And it had that juicy, almost soggy feel that I crave when I look at those Italian pizzas -- I love the way the slices melt in your hand.

CONCLUSION...

If you like thin, chewy, almost soggy (in a good way) pizzas, definitely try Mona Lisa. It was a little pricey though, and the pizzas aren't huge compared to some places' (though my husband and I split one and were totally happy with some to spare... but we're light eaters).

For me, this was the place that satisfied my craving, so I'm quite pleased.
author: Alexa A.

description:
So two stars based on Yelp states, "Meh. I've experienced better". Which is true about this place. Kinda expensive for the food.

If you look past the eagerness and the heavy Italian accent and the typical girl watching, Mona Lisa is one of those places that you have to try once. I've lived in North Beach practically my while life and this is probably my second time here as far as I can remember. I sat outside and it was a bit nippy, but the wine kept me warm. Started off with the bruschetta and it was accompanied with a complimentary trio appetizer consisting of garlic bread, cheesey bread, and a Parmesan bruschetta. That's the good part (free food). I had ordered the Lobster Raviolis. Sorry to say but it lacked flavor all around. It was just blahhh. Maybe it was an off night for them, cause I see all the reviews pointing to it. If you want a mind blowing experience for raviolis, I recommend going to Lorenzo's restaurant. You will spend just a little bit more than Mona Lisa's, but it is worth it. My friend had Italian Sausage with Penne. This was good. Warm, smokey, and not too heavy meal. If I were to go back, I would order this one. That's about it. Wasn't too thrilled about the place.
author: William M.

description:
I love this place, both the food and the decor. I wouldn't say it's the 'best' Italian restaurant I've ever dined at, but it's up there near the top of my list and well worth a try. 

The dim lighting and classic decor give the impression that it would be a nice place for a romantic dinner--but it's usually pretty noisy in there, so I'd scratch it off your list if you're planning a special date.
author: J K.

description:
Saturday night:  "mmmmmm-crap! I forgot to eat today, just drank two vodka soda's and a martini. I'm on a date; starting to shake; slurring may or may not happen soon; and its already 11pm. How do I salvage this date and potentially get some action?"

Food- stat. But the classy semi-date kind. Where to go at 11 pm in North Beach for some kick-ass-take-your-date-home-to-watch-a-movie-cuddle-and-drink-wine Italian food? Mona Lisa. 

We snagged gelato across the street before heading in (FANTASTIC idea...entertained my palate while waiting for the food). We ordered to-go, snagged a taxi, and plated the food with some full glasses of red wine in front of the movie screen. I had the shrimp and asparagus fettuccine, he had the pesto, we both had garlic breath in the morning (wink).

I'm adding this place to my late night need to binge but still maybe seal the deal list.
author: Kaitlyn G.

description:
Eh.

I went here on a date night with my bf. We got a little table in the very corner by the window. The place is defiantly cramped - lots of tables, too many people in such a little space, but it kinda gives it its appeal. We started with the calamari, which was cooked well, but the marinara sauce had far too much raw garlic. I love garlic, but it was a little offensive. 

Next, we had spaghetti carbonara which was made with almost an alfredo sauce, which is not the classic way. The pieces of pancetta were also pretty large too. Not the best we've had. We also had the rigatoni (forgot the name, but with chicken and in a pesto sauce). The chicken was a little overcooked, but otherwise ok. The food is just mediocre. There are plenty of better places to get good, authentic Italian food.
author: Amanda D.

description:
I love Mona Lisa and almost always treat an out-of-town friend to dinner there.  The huge menu is comforting to me in a uniquely Italian way--none of this "Five pastas-yuppie-pseudo-French" crap.  The owner is always ready to greet me, and the wait-staff speaks Italian with an easy-going attitude, very friendly and accommodating.

Whatever we order for dinner, we are always greeted by a *huge* platter of complimentary appetizers.  The cheese-rice balls, the caprese, the bruschetta, the pancetta...all are marvelously prepared and beautifully presented.

I always order one of two dishes: the pasta frontiere (cream and mushroom sauce) or the spaghetti al tono (with tuna).  Interestingly enough, I have asked for different pastas with the same trappings, and *always* the waiter will say, "The cook can't do it that way; that pasta is too thin/wide to hold the sauce well."  I always feel a bit stupid--hey, I'm Italian, and I know this stuff.  Mona Lisa's cooks are always right, and I appreciate the knowledgeable guidance.

The desserts?  Meh.  Leave them alone.  It's the only bad thing I have to say about this place.  Well, that and the coffee.  The former is frozen and tasteless, and the latter pretty vile (instant, I'm sure).

The restaurant went through a period where the portions were really skimpy, but that's been rectified by the owner.  The meals now are generous, but not so heavy that you leave half of the meal on your plate.  The food itself is so good that I don't think my mother could have done better.

Well, maybe *I* couldn't have done better.

In any case, if you're going to eat in North Beach, this is a wonderful place to frequent.  And BTW--if you get down to Pacifica, Mona Lisa has a sister restaurant (Ristorante Portofino).  The food is just as good, although the menu isn't as varied.

Also--be on the lookout for an exotic car parked in front of the restaurant.  Mona Lisa's owner owns a couple of real snazzy jobs!
author: Giovanna M.

description: Went here during the north beach festival.. Had a delicious meal with GREAT service. We had a baby and stroller and they were super accommodating to us. We will be back!!
author: Brooksider C.

description: This restaurant is so beautiful! The atmosphere is very romantic in the evening, which is perfect for dates, anniversaries, or special occasions. The food is good; I usually get the lobster ravioli-- my favorite! I love that the waiters/waitresses are Italian and even speak Italian to each other. It gives the place a real authentic feeling. I suggest making reservations because it is usually very crowded. Four stars only because seating can get a bit tight and the food is a bit pricey.
author: Rebecca C.

description: My mom and I went to this restaurant as San Fran tourists hoping to get some good Italian food in North Beach on our last night. We left feeling really satisfied with the food and the service. The menu is really extensive, but as a vegetarian, I really appreciated the seemlingly bottomless list of vegetarian pastas. We split a tomato, mushroom, and eggplant penne and it was excellent. The pizza was good, very cheesy, and we had some the next morning for breakfast. It was a good overall experience and I recommend the establishment!
author: Brooke B.

description: don't waste your time or money on this joint. $16.95 for spagetti with clams which I don't mind the price if the foods good and a decent proportion. I ordered it with lagunni instead, but got spagetti. The dish was TINY. I am little myself but was starving when I left. The waiter never once came to our table to find out if we liked it or if we needed anything else. We split a ceasar salad. $9.00 and there were like 10 lettuce leaves on the plate with four large croutons. What a joke. The economy has hit this place hard...and the customers paying for it. Don't go. We found a awesome Italian Place on Green Street called Sodinos (i think) which was awesome. A neighborhood joint with large portions. Yummo. Only open for dinner though. Go there instead. It's well worth it.
author: TERRIE G.

description:
My new favorite N. Beach Italian restaurant ! The decor is borderline tacky, which is fun. If you're lucky enough to get a table outside it's fun people watching and the last time we were there we were only panhandled twice.

The food is fantastic ! As a vegetarian I seldom need more than a moment to decide what I'm having because the menu pickings are slim. Here they have over 100 pastas and sauces. My favorite is the ravioli and walnut cream sauce. They are also very generous with their portions!
author: Karen H.

description: Wow! Where do I begin? We came as tourists wanting an authentic experience and Mona Lisa delivered! Loved the real Italian waiters and their charming accents and waving hands. Everyone at the table was more than pleased with their meal (a lot of salmon eaters in our party). It was my mother's birthday and they treated her like a queen. An older gentleman who acted like he might be the owner, was in and out sporting a blue track suit with the Italia (in true to his ethnicity fashion) insignia while people in jeans, in prom dresses, you name it - were filling up the seats with good vibes. Highly recommended. Look for the coolio convertible with the Mona Lisa painted on the hood.
author: Joellen C.

description:
You know, I really liked Mona Lisa the first time I came. If I were already a Yelper, I would have given it 5 stars. This was also 7+ years ago and my first dining experience in San Francisco (born and raised in the South Bay).

Mona Lisa is still pretty tasty and reasonably priced -- given that now I'm more critical than when I was 17. I had the spaghetti bolognese and the antipasto misto to start. The spaghetti gets 4.5 stars (especially for $12) and the antipasto misto gets 1. I guess a nice balance is 3, right?

I'd give Mona Lisa a shot if I were you. It's a cute place and has good spaghetti. Just remember to pass on that soggy appetizer!
author: Han C.

description:
"REVIEWED ON YELP 3.5 STARS"

That can't be too good.  Since when is 3.5 window display worthy?

The front door man couldn't speak English and when we told him we had a reservation he wanted us to point out the time of when we made it for on his watch.  It was annoying and ended up waiting thirty minutes after we made the reservation.  Waiting on the streets, being pushed around by tourist jackoffs and general assholes was not necessarily fun.

But at least once we got in it was a lot better.  Surprisingly enough, the service was extremely attentive and quick.  But I was soon to figure out why.  The waiter told us "Take your time" but after ten minutes and tells us we need to hurry up because of the long line outside.  And towards the end I could feel his frustrations with us.  But between those two times it was nice.  I suppose.

The food was so traditional and amazing! My fish was so delicious and the pasta was obviously fresh.  When it comes to taste it was definitely worth the wait.

If I could give this place a 3.5 I would.

It's crowded, loud, and rushed.  But it's worth at least one visit so you can judge for yourself if you like it.  But personally, I only go out to places on weekend nights that I can make reservations and actually get in at that time.  If you do plan to come, come earlier or come during the weekday.  You'll avoid the assholes and the rush.  It doesn't have your usual touristy jackoffs like they have down the street at the Stinking Rose.  I rather enjoyed this place.
author: Sarah K.

description:
Fun yet classy decor, great staff, decent food, and fantastic prices.  You'll spend roughly $17 a plate but that's pretty good for the food you get.  

Make sure you ask for Giovanni.
author: Josh P.

description:
LOVE this place!!!  There were 6 of us dining for lunch- I had family here from out of town and they wanted good " SF Italian food".  

Mona Lisa was recommended to me and my first time there. The  Service was outstanding as was the food.  They even offer Gluten FREE Pasta!  (2 of us are Gluten Free diners)

Here is what we ordered and the feedback on each:

LASAGNA: "Absolutely awesome. The sause was SO good. I could have just eaten the sauce w/ bread it was so good."

RISOTTO Primavera: "The best l've ever had"

SHRIMP FETTUCCINI ALFREDO: "Gluten Free made to order- it was  delicious!" 

RAVIOLI di POMODORO:"The BEST tomato sauce ever! They served it over huge Fresh ravioli"

CALZONE: " VERY good!! it was exquisite w/ extra tomato sauce."

CHICKEN w/ ARTOCHOKES, TOMATOES served with spinach & potatoes: "DELICIOUS G-FREE available  made  to order.  still rcaving those flavors in my mouth- it makes my mouth water thinking about it."

They left a huge bowl of parmesan cheese that we could add to our meal ourselves.

My new favorite Italian restarant! YUM!!
author: Suzy A.

description: My rating is generous. The place screams "TOURIST TRAP!" and the food is bland. Not authentic Italian by any means. My pasta arrived with several noodles stuck together like when you're a kid learning how to cook fettuccine for the first time. Totally unacceptable!!!
author: Chae P.

description: Whenever we are in town, we love to come here for dinner. The food is always great and so is the wine selection. The restaurant is cozy and the staff is very charming and friendly, especially Marco. It's like running into an old friend whenever we see him. Maurizio the owner is usually there to make sure you are satisfied.  Great place.
author: Irene S.

description:
Yesterday was my first time eating at the Mona Lisa. Our intended destination was this restaurant called the Pinocchio. However as we were walking with our group of about 10 people, there were some Italian people out front of Mona Lisa (quite possibly co-owners) that baited us in with free wine. We were like sure, why not give this place a try. 

The decor is inspired by Renaissance Art. The lighting is not too bright, just kind of right. The interior of the restaurant is shaped like an elongated rectangle. There are various portraits of the Mona Lisa set up throughout the restaurant---surprisingly, even a topless one.

We ordered two appetizers, Calamari and steamed mussel/clams. The Calamari was not bad---fairly tender. The Calms...it was my first time ever eating steamed clams/mussels...they were a somewhat salty, and not bad. Just a different experience. I preferred the calamari instead.

Their complimentary appetizers are slices of (i assume fresh) bread dipped on your plate of your choice of olive oil and red vinaigrette. Sadly i indulged too much on these. Even before my food came, i had realized that----Hey! I'm already kinda getting full---this is not a good sign.

I think i stopped after my 4th piece of bread. I was pretty hungry.

Then the Chicken Parmigiana came. In my honest opinion, their pasta on the side sucks balls. It's pretty bland, flavorless..with a very thin tomato sauce. There also was side of steamed spinach which was not bad, it offset the flavors from the chicken---allowing one to cleanse their pallet before the next bite.

The Chicken on the other hand was exceptionally tender, and the melted cheese on top.....MmMmM delicious! If the meal was maybe $2-$3 cheaper, it would be a bargain....not that ~$15ish a plate is overpriced.

As for the free wine, yes they gave it to us as soon as we were seated. However they carded everyone and the people under 21 didn't get no free wine. Meh, the wine was a bit overrated...again it is just a hook...but hey free is free right? The owners promised two bottles, but no one in our party was really drinking. I myself didn't drink. So we only got one free bottle.

All in all, i give this place a 3.5. Almost a 4 if their pasta was a bit better. 

Also one key observation, there were no female waitresses working their on a Friday night....A bit surprising if you ask me...not that it bothers me a lot.
author: Ahmad s.

description: Wow, this place is amazing!!!  My Cousin and I came here for dinner after a long day of shopping in Chinatown because she had been here before with my Aunt.  The traditional Italian dinner we had (3 hours) was something amazing!   The owner treated us like his closest friends or even family, and mad us feel very at home.  He spoke to my Aunt on the phone and they had a very nice conversation in Italian, after which we were served a wonderful 3 tiered tray of antipasto, complete with calamari, brochetta, prosciutto with melon, fresh wonderful parmigiano regiano, fresh basil and arugula, and a marvelous dipping sauce for the calamari....and that was just for starters. The owner brought us a wonderful bottle of Chianti Classico,which was delicious, and then the main courses.  My Cousin had the Bistecca with fresh porcini mushrooms cooked medium rare, and I had the Vitello Mona Lisa (Veal Mona Lisa), and they were both absolutely wonderful. We finished off the meal with wonderful Lemonciello for desert.  We had to get home unfortunately, but had we not, we would have been happy to stay there and close it down:)  The owner Maurizio took several photographs with us in front of his beautiful Fiat that sits in front of his restaurant that has a picture of the Mona Lisa air-brushed on the hood of his car.  What an amazing ending to a wonderful day.  We HIGHLY RECOMMEND TO ALL,  when in North Beach in San Francisco, or in San Francisco at all, you just have to stop at the Mona Lisa Restaurant for a drink, a meal, or of course both for a truly UNFORGETTABLE EXPERIENCE!!!!!Questo è un meraviglioso di un ristorante di gentile e sempre otterrà un punteggio di cinque stelle da noi sempre!!! Grazie a tutti e saluti a tutti.
author: John A.

description:
Great food choices-tons of variety.

Decor is beautiful and artsy.

Dessert menu could be spruced up a little...
author: Jessica K.

description: The food is outstanding.  I have thoroughly enjoyed several items, including pizza and several different pasta dishes.  The owner is warm and friendly, and the service is great.  I cannot wait to go again.
author: Mary V.

description: Good food served in a unique atmoshere. It is crowded with tables so I wouldn't say intimate or quiet. I like this place for the good authentic Italian fare. A little pricey but so is everything in SF.
author: Dave K.

description:
So before going to mona lisa, like a good yelper I checked it out on yelp first. This restaurant was chosen for me by a friend and she had decided on this restaurant for it's (1) vicinity to bubble lounge, dragon bar and steps of rome without having to get a cab (2) ability to accommodate a party of 14 people for dinner.

So I noticed that the reviews for this place are pretty hit or miss. Some received exceptional service but mediocre food, bad service with mediocre food, some people love the food etc...

Dcor: The descriptions from the yelpers are pretty accurate, there's murals on the ceiling, international flags on the wall, open kitchen area, all the servers wearing mona lisa ties, naked statues, pictures of celebrities that have been to mona lisa... it keeps the eye busy. All the tables are lit by oil lamps, table cloths, cloth napkins, dark furniture, pretty kitschy, pretty typical, you get the point. 

Service: they broke us up into groups of 6, 4 and 4 to make it more manageable.  they seated us immediately (thumbs up!). Service was pretty efficient for a busy restaurant. It got so busy that another server took one of our dishes to his customers who ordered the same thing. we had to call him down to get the dish back. They obviously need to be more organized. Down side was that our long table was sitting parallel to the kitchen which is cool b/c you get the watch the cooks, but it was a high traffic area to be sitting, servers walking by, customers walking by and the occasional gust of cold air when the door opens.

The bathroom had a puddle of water and was super slippery, someone had slipped and fell. She told the server, she acknowledged, but I don't know if they did anything about it.... 

Food: the menu is freaking HUGE. The reason for that is they have EVERY variation of EVERY kind of pasta that you can think of. I would prefer a smaller menu with better food to focus on rather than a wide variety menu, with no focus. i wanted a margarita pizza, but theirs was basically just a cheese pizza. No tomato and basil. Whats up with that??? So I ended up getting the fettuccini primavera. The noodles were a teeeeeny al dente, which is fine with me, the sauce was kind of too creamy for my liking though. I think everyone's general food experience was neither here nor there. it was just Italian food that was not that memorable but still pretty edible. I think the most memorable dish was the Sicilian candy, which is roasted garlic, A LOT of roasted garlic.... 

But I do like how they have the balsamic vinegar and EVOO at the table, and right when your dish comes out, they follow with cheese ASAP. 

I probably wouldn't eat here again, not because it was horribly bad, it was just typical, not special, just very average. if I made the trek all the way out to north beach and bothered to look for parking, I would like something a little more worth my while. Don't you agree??
author: Irene C.

description:
Penne Al Forno Alla Calabrese baked penne with meat sauce, ham and ,mozzarella $13.95

ambiance = dark and tight
parking = depend on your parking fairy...street
staff = strong italian accent and some don't even speak english.  busy that night so it was hard to flag someone down
wait time = long for food, short to be seated
flavor = i liked my dish and that is the only reason why it gets 3 stars

nothing more to say, I think I will try another place.
author: Elisa O.

description:
This place is one of the better North Beach restaurants, with a HUGE menu and some great foods...I especially like the gnocchi dishes.  

I don't really care for the service though.  I called ahead to make reservations on a Friday night, and I still had to wait over an hour for my table, in the same order as people who just walked up.  I thought that was very poor service.  Also, it does take a long time to get your food, etc.

I'd go back again, since its good food and a fun location, but it does have its downfalls.
author: Aaron M.

description:
I feel the need to stand up for this little place so that people who are looking for a good Italian restaurant in the city give it a chance despite some of the more critical reviews. Let me just say that I spent a month in Italy for school and ate out for every meal and this place is where I go when I miss those days and want the real deal..if you are looking for a HUGE selection of every kind of authentic Italian dish under the sun come here. Yes, it is in Little Italy/ North Beach which can be a bit touristy, but that does not mean that it also doesn't have some great places to offer like this one. I also love the look of this restaurant..small and narrow it packs in a ton of paintings on the ceiling and walls and a ton of people for the size of the restaurant. 
I've been coming here for over four years now and have only had two negative experiences..one was trying a sauce that I normally didn't get and ended up not liking and one seemed like just a bad day for the chef, but every other time has been awesome! 

P.S. Try the chicken piccata. It's my favorite and it's hard to find a place that does it right but Mona Lisa succeeds..perfectly tender and flavorful and just the right amount of lemon.
author: Megan B.

description:
Sigmund Freud once interpreted Mona Lisa's smile to signify Leonardo DaVinci's attraction to his mother.  As perverse as incest is, the debate over Mona Lisa's smile is the only good thing to come out of Mona Lisa Restaurant.  I am absolutely shocked at the great reviews for this place.

My wife and were seated in the back of the restaurant and admired the very busy decor of the place.  The carpet looked like a casino floor without the smell of cigarettes surrounded by unique wall paintings.  We both ordered glasses of wine and came back with a very generous pour.  

I ordered Chicken Saltimbocca and my wife had the Tortellini alla Bollognese.  The Chicken Saltimbocca comes with a small serving of marinara pasta and spinach.  Now I'm a fan of olive oil but when I received my entree, the spinach, the pasta, and the chicken were bathing in a nice pool of olive oil laying at the bottom of the plate.  I can understand a little oil, yes it is perhaps an Italian restaurant.  But to take a bath and have the chicken nearly submerged made me believe either the chef was drunk or we had Exxon Valdez part 2 happen in the back of the kitchen.

The chicken itself was only moist because of the oil.  The spinach was drenched in oil.  You get the picture.  I can't make an accurate assessment on the food because I think I ordered chicken with my oil based upon what was served.  The chicken was indeed tasty, but considering it was topped with prosciutto, a layer of cheese and a load of oil, any misgivings about the flavor of the chicken went out the door.  

The wife's tortellini was average.  I think they used Prego sauce.  Even I could've done a better job.  Needless to say she did not finish her entree.

The worst part of the whole experience was the service.  These guys were running around the entire restaurant like chickens with their heads cut off.  They clearly did not have  a handle on nearly anything going on; barking orders at the busboy, water boy, all the while not keeping tabs on their tables.  After we finished the entree the waiter did come by to pick up our plates.  Then for 20 minutes he disappears and is running around taking care of something else.  

"Check please!!"  Been waiting here long enough to have that olive oil grease my colon for Christ's sake!  

Bad food, terrible service.  I don't see how Mona Lisa smiles on this place.
author: Bill P.

description:
Been here twice and both times had some really good food. It's a little cheesy peesy with all the Italian decor, but the food makes up for it. 

With a risotto menu like that, I can overlook the plastic grapes.
author: Bhumika K.

description: Liar. I was walking down the street with my gf looking for a nice place to eat.  The manager called out to me in Italian saying that the food was great and that the pasta was al dente like in Italy.  This brought me in to the restaurant.  The ambience was fine and the service was great, but the pasta was soft ordinary crap.  Pissed me off!  The food is nothing special; the kind of Italian American fare you can find anywhere.
author: Chris L.

description: Excellent service. Mauricio the owner is very personal. Food rocks here. No full bar.
author: Rick P.

description:
This is a must see if you are in San Francisco! It is everything a true Italian Restaurant should be. First of the owner, Maurizio greeted my friend and I with the warmest Ciao! Bella! We had to come in and eat. 
The decor is so over the top it's great! The waiters are all Italian too! I was so excited to practice my skills. We had Giovanni, a Naples local, he was very attentive and recommened my dish, which was amazing!

Don't bother going anywhere else on the street this is by far the best!!!
ciao nicola
author: Nicole R.

description:
My friend and I finally decided on eating here on Thursday around 8 p.m. after walking around the neighborhood. I was going to take her to another restaurant in the area that I frequent more often, but I decided to try something different. We were seated immediately and they let us pick our table. Yay!

I was a bit overwhelmed when we walked in though. There is so much going on inside the restaurant and it looks like it has seen some better days, but after my eyes adjusted, I enjoyed it more. It looks kind of small from the outside, but when you walk in it's huge. It's kind of like you walk into a cave filled with clutter, Italian food and wine. That sounds weird, but it was my first impression.

Now onto the menu and service... The menu was also overwhelming! I was so excited to see the different kinds of gnocchi because I'm a big fan. Although, I was a little leery because I'm picky when it comes to good gnocchi, I ended up getting the four cheese gnocchi and my friend got the pesto gnocchi. 

After our server brought us bread. It was okay, but I've definitely had better at some of the other restaurants in the area. Then they brought our food out and as soon as I dug in to my gnocchi I hated it! I tried my friend's pesto gnocchi and it was delicious. The gnocchi itself was made well, but the sauce was just too much for me sadly. I recommend the dish to people who really *love* cheese. I like cheese, but apparently not that much! 

I felt horrible and contemplated on what to do because I really hate complaining about food. I think our server noticed and he came over right away. He asked me if I'd like to order something else before I couldn't even fumble out words. I nodded apologetically and changed my order to the crab ravioli that comes with a creamy tomato sauce. 

My food was brought out in a good amount of time and I thanked our server profusely because I felt so bad. He was completely cool about it and shrugged it off making the whole meal much more enjoyable.

I will probably come here again because there are so many options and different plates to try, but I will definitely stay away from four cheese anything on the menu. I don't think its a bad sauce. I just think my taste palate isn't used to it. So don't write-off completely. You may end up loving i!t
author: Nicole R.

description:
Came here with a group of 11, and the staff was great about accommodating us. We had to wait on the sidewalk for awhile, but for a Saturday night in North Beach, it wasn't too bad.

It was a little bit crowded and noisy inside, but more in a cozy, lively sense. Mauricio, the owner, checked on us several times and and was extremely friendly and helpful. 

They have an extensive pasta menu, and I really enjoyed my salmon risotto.
author: Jacqueline D.

description:
The menu is a book!!! If you crave anything Italian, they will have it here, including a great wine list. 

The restaurant is decorated elaborately with paintings, sculptures and dark red velvet curtains on the walls. There's a lot to look at as servers bustle by carrying delicious smelling dishes. I ordered a meat with cheese rigatoni and it was very tasty. I like the complimentary bread with olive oil too. 

The portions were perfect, the service was friend and the food was tasty! Yum, I can't wait to come back. 

Grazie!
author: Gladys C.

description:
- 1 star because we were pressured to eat by 3 annoying tough guys. 

but HELLOOOO to my ravioli with porcini mushrooms.
author: Alicia V.

description:
North Beach usually makes me a little sketchy since it's a lot of tourists and usually that means overpriced, un-authentic Italian food...for a nice little Sicilian girl like myself, I cannot be content with mediocre pastas covered in messy sauces of canned tomatoes covered in cheese to hide its imperfections. so why we ended up at such a touristy joint is beyond me, but their veggie lasagna did the job...it was hearty yet light enough to still enjoy the buzz from the pinot grigio with our antipasti, score!
service was ok, but our server lingered a little too long (can't a group of girls entertain each other in our own company, not yours?), and made weird comments that left us a little puzzled. I'd probably go back for the food, not for our new "best friend"
author: Danielle D.

description:
The food here is wholly average, the service is friendly but extremely slow, the prices are far higher than they should be. Considering that North Beach is teeming with Italian restaurants, you would think that some of these places might want to up their game some. We were lured in with the promise of free bruschetta, but it never arrived. The child's plate of pasta was humongous and $8.00. The wine list was crappy, but priced as if you might actually get a decent glass (out of a box that they must keep under the bar).

I started with the steamed mussels and clams appetizer which was all right, but nothing special at all and I was a more than a little disappointed by the very tomato saucy sauce they came in. It was nothing like I had ever seen before and expected it to be more wine and broth than what seemed like canned tomato puree. My friend had a Caesar with grilled shrimp that she enjoyed, though she dislikes dressing, so I wasn't able to taste it... I often judge places by their caesar dressing. As an entree, I had the veal picatta. While the sauce was lovely and the side dishes were great, the veal itself was overcooked and very tough. My friend had the chicken parmesan and she said that it was "just fine". I ate her spinach.

My biggest problem with the place is that the service was so so sooooo slow. Even though when we arrived there were only two other tables sat, it took a ridiculous amount of time to get our orders in and be served. Getting the check took almost 20 minutes, until I finally had it and just brought my card to the server.
author: Brandi V.

description:
Meh.

Came here with a friend for an early dinner. The place was fairly empty so the service was decent. Our waiter was very sweet and took good care of us.

The food was mediocre. We shared a bottle of wine, a caprese salad and a penne dish. The wine was fine for $24 bucks. The caprese was hurtin', the tomatoes weren't even close to ripe. The penne was delish, especially since I requested that they add fresh mozzarella to the dish.  

I don't think I'll ever have the need to return to Mona Lisa, there are far too many restaurants in North Beach to explore. But our time spent at Mona Lisa was certainly enjoyable none-the-less.
author: alexa c.

description:
DANG this place still pleases me after all these years!! it could be the semi-cute staff that flirts with me in italian, or that their food is de-lish. ;) i'm thinking it's the man ass. 

i had lunch on friday with my work husband and inhaled my gnocchi sorrentina. husband had something chickeny, which looked mighty tasty, but i didn't dare snag a bite. the service was great and we were in and out in no time flat! it's a good thing i'm still on the no-booze thing, otherwise i'm fairly certain i would have ordered a couple bottles of wine and would have been a total mess walking back tot he office! :o
author: Kristin Y.

description:
I sort of want to come up with something snobby to say about this place and/or Little Italy, but the fact is it just satisfies.

Cozy atmosphere, friendly service, and at 2pm on a holiday, our food came quickly!

Yum.
author: Meghan B.

description:
This is hands down my favorite restaurants in North Beach and close to being one of my favorite restaurants in the city.  Your treated with Italian love and hospitality before you even walk in the door because every time I walk by this place this is a smiling Italian man waving me in.  Once you get inside look up and if your lucky enough to have visited Rome in your time then you will notice that is is a very familiar site.  They have painted a replica of the Celestine Chapel on the restaurant ceiling!  Complete with the hand of God and Adam reaching for each other.  When you sit down you are presented with a complimentary plate of bruschetta.  Putting food in front of you without even asking if you want it as an Italian I can tell you that's a sign of a true Italian!  Loving this place before I even look at the menu.  

The menu, it gets even better here.  It's like book!! Pages and pages of every imaginable pasta option out there and all of the glorious entree options you would expect and love.  I can never make up my mind that's another reason to come to this place time after time.  Now you would think they could run the risk of offering too much and not getting every dish right, but so not true.  Every plate that I have had at Mona Lisa has been delicious.  One of my more memorable experiences was with the Gorgonzola Walnut Ravioli- To-die-for!  I even came here when I was on a Vegan fast and could not eat ANY animal products.  The accomidating server came up with with meat-free, cream-free, cheese-free risotto that was simply out of this world!  I have never had dessert here because the people I'm with are alway too full by that point in the meal.  But not be I'm never too full, there is always that special spot left in the stomach that doesn't get full because it's meant for sweets.  

When you come here come hungry and get ready to mangi mangi!
author: Marlene S.

description: I have been coming to eat at Mona Lisa for several years now. Always great service, great ambiance, very enjoyable.
author: Grid A.

description: WARNING: do not plan to come to come here if you are hungover, tired, really hungry, or desire a mimosa. Only here come here if you have an entire day to spare waiting and waiting.
author: Joshua G.

description: I'm often in town for work and cannot leave for home until I visit Mona Lisa. I'm a native Italian and tend to have high standards when I visit Italian restaurants. Everything from the ambiance to the food and wait staff reminds me of home. The staff is extremely friendly and knowledgable of their wine list and food menu. The owner is a genuinely kind man, passionate about his food and willing to take the time to meet his patrons. The food is truly exquisite and simply fresh. You cannot go wrong with any fish item as they prepare to perfection. The same goes for the pasta as it is always al dente, topped with the most delicious sauces and freshest ingredients. Mona Lisa does not disappoint. Give it a taste and you'll be transported to the shores of the Mediterranean Sea. Bon apetit!
author: Christina C.

description:
Horrible, Horrible, Horrible. Shame on us for not taking the first clue of waiting 30 minutes just to place our meal order. We were discussing leaving after I noticed that there were several wait staff standing around and only one other table of diners on an early Sunday evening. Unfortunately, a waiter showed up with absolutely no apology and we stuck around. I'm still kicking myself! 

I was enticed by the description of the "home made" pasta. I don't know how many years ago the pasta was made but most of my manicotti was left on the plate because I couldn't saw through it. Overcooked to say the least. The sauce reminded me of something out of a Kitchen Nightmares episode. My son's gnocchi was average and for all I know, the caesar salad was made from a kit purchased at Safeway. 

I'm relieved to report we did not get sick but I will absolutely never go back. Too many awesome options in SF.
author: Rhonda H.

description: The pasta here is very delicious!  If you're on the fence about where to go in San Fran for a good meal, give Mona Lisa a try.
author: Adrienne M.

description: During our recent SF vacation local friends mentioned this as a good place for lunch. It's touristy, but locals go there too, is how they described it. The place definitely has an Italian vibe, and the decor is verging on over the top, but not quite. We were on foot and strolled in around the lunch hour on a week day. The place was pretty quiet and we were seated right away. Our waiter was attentive and friendly, and definitely Italian. The three of us ordered pasta of one kind or another, and a salad. Everything was very good. Prices weren't necessarily cheap, but this is a popular restaurant in downtown SF, so what can you expect? If you want to get your pasta-pizza on, this is your place.
author: Bob D.

description:
Reservations for eight - arrived early, and sat down on time. 

The friendly wait staff was knowledgeable about the menu.  Recommendations came swiftly, and service was excellent given that the place was packed and partially occupied by a few needy parties.  

Design - definitely a conversation starter.  Pictures of celebrities, renditions of famous Italian paintings and murals...it definitely kept us busy while we waited for our food.  

The atmosphere - louder in some parts than others, but that's fine.  Definitely a fun atmosphere in the back. 

Food: We all sampled each other's dishes, and they were great. 

The meat dish appetizer was delicious.  

The chicken saltimbocca (and veal saltimbocca) was great.  Good portions and flavored well.  The chicken was done perfectly, the cheese was on par, the sauteed spinach was so good, and the sauce was delicious.  

My friend's four cheese sauce gnocchi was good, and I'm not a cheese sauce fan at all.  

Let's face it, Italian cuisine isn't exactly known for its dessert.  In fact, most other Italian restaurants have a pretty bland list of desserts.  

But Mona Lisa prepares desserts that made me realize why dinner out should always be three courses.  They were aesthetically pleasing, and tasty.  Just check out their menu.  Honestly.
author: Andrew D.

description:
We had a party of three and waited for 20 min.  There was this guy who had a party of 2 and was seated immediately as he shook hands with the hostess.  The lady waiting for a table for two walked off after witnessing that. Then there was another couple was wondering what just happened.  Did they just get cut?

Food: Nothing special.  The mussels for appetizers were way overcooked and was somewhat nasty. They shrunk beyond half their shell size.  My entree was just ok.  So that meant everyone else's entree was ok because they all tasted the same, whether it's seafood or meat. 

It''s not worth the wait.  And with the fear of line cuts to homeboy's  boofing buddies, I would not go back.

stinky tofu
author: StinkyTofu S.

description:
So my husband & I were in Rome searching late at night for a hotel.  We were lucky to find a place and meet a nice Italian that lived in SF for awhile and worked at Mona Lisa in North Beach.  He was excited to talk to us about SF and told us next time we are in North Beach stop by and tell his friends hi.  
WE did just that...we got great service, some appetizers on the house, and the food was tasty.  I can't remember our little friends name anymore but I am glad to have checked this place out.
author: Michelle M.

description:
QUICK!! Think of ANY type of pasta off the top of your head...any type!

I can almost guarantee you that Mona Lisa has it. I have been here many times and I've yet to find something that I don't like. Maybe I'm an old fashioned Italian girl, but I like my dishes to be simple. Mona Lisa gives me that. Their menu consists of every type of noodle and then at least 10 different sauces that you can put on it. Seriously, at least 10! (I recommend any of the Gnocchi's! Delicious!)  They also have a great wine list (go for the Reisling, affordable and very yummy!) 

The decor in the place makes me think that I am back in Italy on the one week that I actually spent there! It's clustered to perfection! 

SOMETHING TO CHECK OUT! Just outside the restaurant is a huge map of Italy painted on the building with a bunch of signatures of tourists/locals and where their family is from. It's amazing to just look at!
author: Heather T.

description:
The food at Mona Lisa's is very good, ranging from a wide variety of italian dishes that taste great. The service is fair depending on the time of day you go (night is a bit slow) and the servers are fairly nice. They also usually give your table a free appetizer depending on the size, so bring lots of people and get lots of free appetizers.

Getting seated on the other hand, is a bit troublesome. It takes forever to get seated b/c the restaurant can only accommodate a small number of people (needs to expand to a bigger place).

None the less, the restaurant is good if your looking for tasty Italian dishes, but be expected to cash out some money, cuz food there isn't cheap
author: Dylan T.

description:
After being here for almost 8 months, I thought I'd be better at avoiding a complete tourist trap.  But then again, I don't put a lot of hang time down in North Beach, so I guess that's my excuse.

  Five of us went on a Friday night of a 95-degree day, hoping for an outside table somewhere in the 'hood.  Of course, every place was like a can of hot, stanky sardines, with people spilling out onto the thoroughfare.  (It seems though the HVAC as well as the armpits of San Francisco are not prepared for hot days.)

  We spied some peeps finishing their salads at Mona Lisa and got on the wait for their table.  Twenty minutes later, we were sitting outside with menus, but it was a long time before our very flustered server arrived.  We ate lots of bread, which was a tad Safeway-esque.

  We ended up with two bottles of the $27.00 Sauvignon Blanc, which was tasty for the price.  (We should not have had 2 bottles, but that was something I would discover much, much later in the evening.) 

  The Fritto Misto was a good choice of appetizer, along with the sampler that included bruschetta.  Salads were not spectacular, but made me feel healthier about what I was going to eat next.

  My pumpkin ravioli with brown butter sauce was super Bret Michaels- dangerously rich with nothing on the top.   Other attendees thought their dishes- the gnocchi in particular- were of BM status too and none of us could finish.

  We were seated right next to a speaker that was WAY too loud, and when you threw in the warbly, intermittent Italian solos coming from the front door man, it was like a bad theater experience.  

  With the tinny tunes and being too full for dessert, we paid our 184.00 and bid au revoir to Mona Lisa.  I spent the evening with a roiling tummy who was clearly unhappy with its' current contents.

Damn you, Bret Michaels.
author: Lea N.

description: Food Quality is very average. My spaghetti carbonara was salty and overcooked. Prices are too high for this quality. A t-bone steak for $30 is much higher than the most steakhouses. The service is OK. The ambient is nice. The tiramisu was not so good as I expect from an Italian restaurant. I make it much more better by myself.
author: Rokgoo R.

description: Great service and the best Italian restaurant in North Beach. Love the squid ink linguini!
author: Rebecca Q.

description: Not super impressed. Service was not that good either. Sad that I chose this place for my one dinner in San Francisco.
author: Sarah S.

description: My friends and I came here to drown our our sorrow after a  USC stanford game. I really liked the atmosphere here just because it was so ornamented and the gnocchi looked amazing. But I stuck to the rissoto which wasn't too bad- but it was more... rice than anything else. And my friend got an arugula salad which was way to expensive for what it was. So he got a little upset and nobody really gave us the time of day with service. So.. 2 stars.
author: Tinaa W.

description: Mona Lisa is one of the best restaurants on Columbus Street in North Beach.  My favorite thing to do is eat outside or near the window as it makes me feel like I'm back in Italy.  Even the waiters all can speak Italian.  One day I want to eat in the little car parked outside the restaurant.  There is a huge selection on the menu but my favorite dishes are the Cioppino, ravioli with truffle sauce and calamari.  On top of the delicious food, the service was superb.  I would recommend asking Ciro for your dining experience as he is very attentive and provides great suggestions for trying new dishes.
author: Wendy W.

description:
terrible ! in one word .... got 50% off from scout mob .... problem is  , is their prices are so high .. the 50% off price is what they should have cost in the first place !!!! 10.50$ for minnistrone soup !!??   what is that about ???
and a menu this big is never a good thing !! also   pretty dirty inside!!
author: Micah W.

description:
This was my second visit and although I was still pleased by the overall quality of the food to have a 20% tip added to the bill I still found a bit cheeky as we were only a table of 4...

The menu is large and robust with something for everyone, while the wine list is reasonable in both scope and price.

The staff are courteous and helpful however I am still unipressed with the 20% add on. :/
author: Lulu R.

description:
Delicious waiters...not so delicious food. This place could be so much better - fabulous interiors, attentive staff, good vibes, but the chef must be from Tibet because any red-blooded Italian KNOWS that risotto is made with arborio rice and not the el cheapo long grain stuff. For a place that touts 18 varieties of risotto, this is a food crime non pareil.  My date had a penne pasta with a sauce that came from cans, and the olive oil served with the bread was tasteless.
